text: Text: 'Some time ago, a website talked about the dangers of public check-ins – telling everyone online where you are. The website's message was clear: you might think you are just saying, ‘Hey, I’m here’ – but you are also telling everyone, even people you don’t know. This made people think that sharing too much online might not be good. The internet lets us share everything about our lives with many people. This can be exciting: maybe we can become rich or famous! So, we share our secrets, photos, and stories online. But later, we might find out that it is not safe, and we feel lost. Is this sad? Maybe, but don’t worry. There is a way to understand this. A long time ago, some people started sharing their lives online. They learned about the dangers before social media was popular. These people, called bloggers, have already experienced what we are going through now. We should learn from them. In January 1994, Justin Hall, a 19-year-old student, started posting on the ‘WWW’, which was mostly used by students and scientists. The web was created at Cern, a lab in Switzerland, to help researchers share their work. Hall saw it as a way to share his life. He wrote about himself and shared photos and art. In January 1996, he started a daily blog, and many people read about his life. Hall shared everything: if you met him, you might be on his site; no topic was off-limits. One day, his website disappeared, and there was only a sad video called Dark Night. He had fallen in love, but when he wrote about it, he was told ‘either the blog goes, or I do’. He learned that sharing too much online can make people not trust you. The blog stopped, but the problem is still here. Sharing online is fun. But if you think it will make people like you, you might be wrong. In 2002, Heather Armstrong, a young woman in Los Angeles, had a blog called Dooce. She sometimes wrote about her job. One day, someone at her work sent her blog to the bosses, and she lost her job. People who study the internet call this the ‘online distribution effect’: we feel we can say things online that we wouldn’t say in person. But the internet is not a place where we can say anything without consequences. Our online lives are connected to our real lives. If we forget this, we can make big mistakes. Armstrong’s story ended well. She was sad and stopped blogging for a while, but she got married and started her blog again, writing about her family. Now, she is famous among ‘mommy bloggers’ and her blog helps her family. She learned that even though we can say anything online, it doesn’t mean we should.'

Text: Some scientists started a campaign to warn people about a film called "What the Bleep Do We Know?" This film mixed documentary and drama to show that there is a lot about our universe we do not understand. Scientists usually agree with this idea because no one knows everything about the universe. However, some scientists were worried about the film and called it "atrocious" and "dangerous." 

At first, the film seemed normal. Scientists talked about how new discoveries show the universe is stranger than we thought. But then, the film talked about discoveries like water molecules being changed by thoughts. A Japanese researcher said that the shape of a water molecule could change just by the thoughts of people around it. The film showed pictures of ice crystals looking nice after being talked to by someone happy, and looking bad after being talked to by someone in a bad mood. Some people found this interesting, but many scientists said, "Give me a break." They wanted better proof.

The film's claims were not strange enough. Scientists have found that the universe is made of unknown matter and is expanding because of a mysterious force called "dark energy." Other discoveries are also amazing. Neuroscientists found that our brain takes about half a second to understand what we see, but we do not notice this delay. Anthropologists think they know where modern humans first lived and why they moved to other places. Some scientists think there is a link between life on Earth and the design of the universe.

Science is not finished. We are learning more and more, and many things in nature are still hard to understand. Theories like chaos and quantum uncertainty show limits to what we can know. Some physicists are trying to create a "Theory of Everything" to explain all forces and particles in the universe. Many people think the universe is incredible.

Text: 'For me, writing novels is hard, but writing short stories is fun. Writing a novel is like planting a forest, and writing a short story is like planting a garden. Both are important and make a beautiful picture together. The trees in the forest give shade, and the wind moves the leaves. In the garden, flowers bloom, and bees and butterflies come. Since I started writing, I have switched between novels and short stories. After I finish a novel, I want to write short stories. After I finish short stories, I want to write a novel. I never write both at the same time. Writing novels and short stories might use different parts of the brain, and it takes time to change from one to the other. I started with two short novels in 1975, and then I wrote short stories from 1984 to 1985. I didn’t know much about writing short stories then, but it was a memorable experience. My world of stories grew bigger, and readers liked this new side of me. One of my first stories, ‘Breaking Waves’, was in my first short-story book, Tales from Abroad. Writing short stories is nice because they don’t take long to finish. It usually takes me about a week to make a short story good (though I can revise them a lot). It’s not like writing a novel, which takes a year or two. You can finish a short story quickly. Writing a novel feels like it takes forever, and I sometimes wonder if I will finish. So, writing short stories is a nice change. Another good thing about short stories is that you can make them from small ideas, like a word or an image. It’s like jazz music, where the story goes where it wants. If a story doesn’t work, it’s okay. Not every story is great, even for famous writers like F. Scott Fitzgerald and Raymond Carver. This makes me feel better. You can learn from mistakes and use that in the next story. When I write novels, I try to learn from my short stories. Short stories are like a test place for me as a novelist. It’s hard to try new things in a novel, so short stories help me. My short stories are like soft shadows or footprints I leave behind. I remember each one and how I felt. They are like signs to my heart, and I am happy to share these feelings with my readers.'

Text: 'Science is a big part of our lives. It helps us understand the world and can cure diseases. Science can make life easier, but it can also be dangerous. Scientists try to understand small things like atoms and big things like the universe. Science has changed many ideas in history. Sometimes, new ideas in science are not accepted at first, but later they become important. Scientists often disagree with each other. Science is always changing. One scientist might prove another scientist wrong. This can change what we believe about the world. In the past, people thought they knew everything about physics, but then new discoveries like X-rays and the Big Bang changed that. Science is not just for scientists. It affects everyone. We need to understand science because it can change our future and the world we live in. Science is important for making decisions about health, money, and the environment. It is important for everyone to know about science, not just scientists.'

Text: 'Around 2015, big publishers noticed that ebook sales stopped growing or even went down. This made people question if ebooks would be important in the future. One publishing boss said that the excitement about ebooks might have led to bad investments. His company lost faith in the power of printed books. Even though digital and print books can exist together, people still ask if ebooks will replace print books. This idea makes us think and talk a lot. Why do we see ebooks and print books as fighting each other? The answer is about how we feel about new things. In my research, I found that people often think new technology will replace old ones. For example, when TV was invented, people thought radio would disappear. But radio survived by finding new uses, like in cars. The idea of books disappearing is not new. In 1894, people thought phonographs would replace books with what we now call audiobooks. This has happened many times. Movies, radio, TV, and smartphones were all thought to end print books. Some people worried this would hurt culture, while others thought ebooks were better. The idea of books disappearing comes up when new technology appears. This shows our mixed feelings about change. We have strong feelings for things like books and computers because they are part of our lives. When new technology comes, we have to change our connection with these things. This makes us miss what we used to have. That's why there are businesses for old products. For example, when the printing press spread in the 15th century, people wanted old manuscripts. When movies got sound in the 1920s, people missed silent films. The same happened with digital photography and CDs. E-readers made people appreciate old books more, even their smell. This should comfort those worried about print books disappearing. But the idea of disappearing media will continue to be a story about technology's power and our fear of change. We use stories to understand change, like stories of endings. The story of the death of the book shows our excitement for the future and our fear of losing what we know.'

Text: 'Almost every weekday morning for a year and a half, I woke up at 5:30, brushed my teeth, made coffee, and sat down to write. I wrote about how some of the greatest minds of the past 400 years found time each day to do their best work. I looked at their daily schedules to see how they were creative and productive. By writing about their daily lives – when they slept, ate, worked, and worried – I wanted to show a new side of their personalities and careers. I wanted to show that they were like us, with habits and routines. The French gastronome Jean Anthelme Brillat-Savarin once said, ‘Tell me what you eat, and I shall tell you what you are.’ I say, ‘Tell me what time you eat, and if you take a nap afterward.’ This book is about the circumstances of creative activity, not the product. It’s about how people work, not what they make. But it’s also personal. The novelist John Cheever thought that even a business letter shows something of your inner self. My book looks at questions I think about in my own life: How do you do meaningful creative work while also earning a living? Is it better to focus completely on a project or to work on it a little each day? When there isn’t enough time for everything, do you give things up, or do you learn to do more in less time? I don’t have all the answers, but I give examples of how successful people faced these challenges. I wanted to show how big creative ideas come from small daily actions; how your habits affect your work, and vice versa. The book’s title is Daily Rituals, but it’s really about people’s routines. A routine can seem ordinary, but it can help you use your time, willpower, and optimism well. A good routine helps you focus and avoid being controlled by your moods. The psychologist William James thought you should put part of your life on autopilot; by forming good habits, he said, we can focus on more interesting things. Ironically, James himself was a procrastinator and couldn’t stick to a schedule. This book started from my own procrastination. One Sunday, I was at work trying to write a story due the next day. Instead of working, I was tidying my desk and making coffee. I’m a ‘morning person’ and can focus well in the morning but not after lunch. That afternoon, I searched the Internet for other writers’ schedules. I found many interesting stories and thought someone should collect them. So, I started the Daily Routines blog and now, this book. The blog was simple; I posted descriptions of people’s routines from biographies, magazine profiles, and newspaper obituaries. For the book, I expanded and researched more, keeping the short and varied voices that made the blog popular. I let my subjects speak for themselves through quotes from letters, diaries, and interviews. In other cases, I summarized their routines from other sources. This book wouldn’t be possible without the work of many biographers, journalists, and scholars. I have listed all my sources in the Notes section, which can also guide further reading.'

Howard became a palaeontologist because of something that happened when he was six years old. His father, who was careful with money, decided they could not go on holiday to Spain because it was too expensive. Instead, they went to the English coast. There, Howard found an ammonite* on the beach. From that moment, he knew he wanted to study fossils. At university, he decided he wanted to study very old fossils, not dinosaurs. He liked studying small, ancient creatures in rocks.

After finishing his studies, Howard worried about finding a job. He knew he was good, but getting a job was not always fair. He applied for a job at Tavistock College in London. On the day of his interview, the professor who liked another candidate had an accident and could not attend. Another professor, who did not like the first professor, helped Howard get the job. Howard was happy to get the job, even though he later learned it was because of the professors' disagreement.

Howard enjoyed his work, but he knew life could be unpredictable. One day, someone stole his briefcase with important notes. He was upset but went back to the college. There, he met a visitor from the Natural History Museum in Nairobi. He learned about a new collection of fossils that needed studying. This was a big opportunity for him. Because of the theft, he changed his plans. He decided not to go to a conference in Stockholm or take students to Scotland. Instead, he would find a way to visit the museum in Nairobi.

*An ammonite is a type of fossil.

Charles Spence will eat almost anything. "We have ice cream made from bee larvae at home," says the Professor of Experimental Psychology at Oxford University in the UK. The larvae may look like maggots, but they taste "slightly nutty, floral." Making bug-eating normal is one of the many food challenges Spence and his team are working on. Spence studies how our senses work together to create the taste of food. He influences what we eat and drink, from big food companies to top restaurants. Spence and his team study how we experience food and drink. Who we eat with, how food looks and is described, the color and weight of plates and cutlery, and background noise all affect taste. Spence’s book, The Perfect Meal, written with Betina Piqueras-Fiszman, is full of interesting facts about eating. Did you know that the first person to order in a restaurant enjoys their food the most? Or that we eat about 35% more food when eating with one other person, and 75% more with three others? Spence’s lab in Oxford is simple. "Low-tech, paper and drawing pin stuff," he says. There are soundproof booths and old audio-visual equipment. By keeping costs low, he can work with cooks who can’t pay for research. Much of his work is funded by a big food company. In the past, research with industry money was seen as "not real science" in universities. But now, universities must show their work has an impact, so this research is important. Spence is helping famous brands reduce salt and sugar. They do it slowly, so customers don’t notice the change. "When you tell people what you’re doing, they focus on the taste and don’t like it as much," he says. Spence met Heston Blumenthal, a famous chef, while working on a project. People thought "Science and food – that’s horrible," but most food is scientific. Blumenthal and Spence created the "Sound of the Sea" dish in Blumenthal’s restaurant. Spence says that the Italian futurists were "doing sounds of croaking frogs with frogs legs a century ago," but it didn’t become popular. Now the food industry uses Spence’s sensory science. His research shows that high-pitched music makes food taste sweeter, and low-pitched sounds make it taste bitter. An airline will soon match music with food for passengers. Last year, a brand released a smartphone app that played music while your ice cream softens, but they didn’t match the music to the taste. What are dinner parties like at Spence’s home? Once, they ate rabbit with fur on the cutlery. Another time, they used remote-controlled lights. "We’ve had dinner parties with a tone generator, headphones, and 10 different drinks to see if they have different pitches." Home, sweet shops, food conventions, and international food conferences are all part of Spence’s lab.

Text: 'Our brains are busier than ever before. We have to deal with facts, fake facts, and rumours, all pretending to be information. We need to find out what is important and what we can ignore. At the same time, we are doing more things. Thirty years ago, travel agents booked our flights and salespeople helped us in shops. Now we do most things ourselves. We are doing the work of many people while trying to keep up with our lives, families, jobs, hobbies, and TV shows. Our smartphones help us do all this. They are part of the 21st-century habit of filling every spare moment. But there is a problem. We think we are multitasking – doing many things at once – but this is not true. Earl Miller, a brain expert at MIT, says our brains are not good at multitasking. When we think we are multitasking, we are actually switching from one task to another very quickly. This switching has a cost. We are not like expert jugglers; we are more like beginners, moving from one task to another and worrying that something will go wrong. Even though we think we are doing a lot, multitasking makes us less efficient. It increases stress hormones, which can make our thinking unclear. Multitasking makes us want more new things, distracting us. The part of the brain we need to focus is easily distracted. Just having the chance to multitask can hurt our brain performance. Glenn Wilson, a psychology expert, calls it info-mania. His research shows that trying to focus on a task while an email is unread can lower your IQ by almost 10 points. This is worse than being tired. Russ Poldrack, a brain scientist at Stanford, found that learning while multitasking sends information to the wrong part of the brain. If students do homework and watch TV at the same time, the information goes to a part of the brain for skills, not facts. Without TV, the information goes to a part of the brain where it is easier to remember. Multitasking also needs decision-making: ‘Do I answer this text or ignore it?’ Making decisions is hard for our brains. After many small decisions, we can make bad decisions about important things. Business leaders, scientists, and writers say email is a problem. It is not about email itself, but the large amount of communication. A colleague's 10-year-old son said his father’s job is ‘answering emails.’ This is almost true. We feel we must reply to emails, but it seems impossible to do so and get other things done.'

Text: 'In a Swedish zoo, a chimpanzee named Santino broke concrete into pieces at night to throw at visitors during the day. Was he being mean? In caves in the US, female bats help other fruit bat mothers if they can’t find the right position to give birth. Are they being kind? Fifty years ago, these questions were not important. Animals had behaviors, and science recorded what happened. The idea that animals have feelings and thoughts was not taken seriously. But recently, this has started to change. Research on bats, chimps, rats, dolphins, and chickens shows that animal emotions are now being studied. This change has led to books like Mark Bekoff’s Wild Justice and Victoria Braithwaite’s Do Fish Feel Pain?. It has started a debate: do animals have consciousness? This leads to another question: do animals have a sense of right and wrong? In a recent experiment, cows had to open a locked gate to get food. Cows that opened the gate themselves showed more happiness by jumping and kicking than those that had help. If cows enjoy solving problems, what does this mean for eating beef? The observations are clear, but people disagree on what they mean. Dr. Jonathan Balcombe, author of Second Nature, believes we should stop eating meat. He thinks we are near a big change in how we treat animals. Aubrey Manning, a professor at Edinburgh University, says we should rethink how we see animal intelligence. He believes animals have a simpler mind than humans. Professor Euan MacPhail thinks we should stop giving animals human traits. The disagreement is not just scientific or moral, but philosophical. Can we ever know what it is like to be a bat? Balcombe talks about an experiment with starlings, a type of bird, that he thinks shows they can get depressed. At Newcastle University, starlings were put in two groups. One group had nice cages with space and water. The other group had small, empty cages. Both groups learned to eat tasty worms from one box and avoid bad worms from another. Later, when only bad worms were offered, only the birds in nice cages ate them. Balcombe thinks the birds in bad cages felt pessimistic. Balcombe, who works with animal rights groups, believes we will one day see our treatment of animals as wrong, like racism. If he were alone in this view, it might be easy to ignore him. But Professor Aubrey Manning agrees with him. Manning has written a book, An Introduction to Animal Behaviour. He says we are changing how we think about animals. It is a difficult topic, and people have strong opinions.'

Text: Critical thinking is a way to understand better what we read or hear. Adrian West, from the Edward de Bono Foundation U.K., says that argument helps find the truth. Technology helps us store and process information, but it might change how we solve problems. We see a lot of poor thinking and opinions, which can confuse us. More data does not always mean better knowledge or decisions. Reading books has gone down, says the National Endowment for the Arts. Patricia Greenfield, a psychology professor, thinks less reading might mean less critical thinking. People focus more on quick media and doing many things at once. We do not know exactly how technology affects thinking. Computers and the internet can be good or bad for thinking. For example, a computer game might help or hurt critical thinking. Reading online can help analyze, but too many links can stop deep thinking. Greenfield says technology changes how we think. Reading helps imagination and critical thinking more than video games and TV. But visual media can improve some information skills. Most visual media do not give time for thinking or imagination. This can make people, especially young ones, not use their full abilities. How we see technology affects how we think about critical thinking. Video games and thinking skills are a big topic. James Paul Gee, an educational psychology professor, says video games can be good for learning. Games like Sim City and Civilization teach decision-making and thinking skills. They let people explore ideas in a virtual world. In the digital age, as reading and math scores go down, we need to understand how technology affects thinking.

Text: 'Matthew Crawford is a motorcycle mechanic. Before this, he worked in an office but did not like it. He wrote a book about why working with your hands is good. His new book talks about how to live in the modern world. He got the idea when he saw ads on a credit card machine while shopping. Crawford thinks these ads make it hard for us to focus. We can't choose what to think about because of these distractions. This makes it hard to talk to people or remember things. We often use phones and apps, which can control our attention. Many people feel the same way. For example, some office workers complain about emails but still check them all the time. Studies show that just seeing a phone can distract us. There is no proof yet that our attention spans are shorter, but we are more aware of other things we could be doing. Crawford believes technology makes us focus too much on ourselves. We prefer texting to talking because it feels safer. This can make us lose real connections with people. Crawford gives an example from his gym. Before, there was one music player for everyone. Now, people use earphones and listen to their own music. This change makes the gym less social. Crawford suggests two solutions. First, we should have rules to reduce noise and distractions in public. Second, we should do activities that need skill, like cooking or playing sports. These activities help us connect with the real world. They make us use our judgment and work with others. This way, we can focus better and enjoy life more.'

Text: "What do you do for a living?" This is a common question. We often talk about our jobs. But when you are a philosopher, like me, it is a bit harder to answer. Saying you are a philosopher can sound a bit too serious. People might think you have special knowledge. But philosophers are just like everyone else. So, why do people think philosophers are different? One reason is that philosophers think a lot about life and ideas. A Greek philosopher, Aristotle, said that thinking about life is the best way to live. Another Greek philosopher, Socrates, said that we should think about our lives to make them better. This does not mean you have to read many books or think all the time. It just means looking at your life and making sure it is good. Philosophy should help people in their daily lives. But today, philosophy in universities is often very complicated. It is hard for people who are not experts to understand. This is because philosophers write in expensive journals that not everyone can read. So, philosophy seems far from real life. I sometimes call myself an "ethicist" because I study ethics, which is about what is right and wrong. But ethics is not just about rules and laws. It is also about thinking deeply about our actions. For example, we might ask if downloading movies illegally is wrong. Then, we can think about responsibility and our views on art. Philosophy helps us look closely at our lives. Sometimes we find out things we already know. Other times, we learn new things. By thinking about these ideas, we can help everyone.

Text: 'People who love food, like chefs and food lovers, might think that thinking about what and how we eat can make eating more enjoyable. But in history, talking about food was often used to talk about other things, like learning. Sometimes, when people talked about food, they were really talking about other ideas. An interesting example is the Greek philosopher Epicurus. He talked about enjoying life and avoiding pain in many ways. But today, his name is often linked to enjoying food and drink. We see his name in restaurants and food shops because they think it will help them sell more. Food is social and cultural. It comes from history and is shared with people around us. We eat with others and get our food from our communities. We deal with food more than any other thing, so it is a good topic to think about. After food is made, people talk and write about it. But why do some people have a special status when they talk about food? One philosopher says that tasting food is not a special skill, but some people are just better at describing it. Most studies about how we see things focus on vision, not taste, and this should change. Another part of food is how it looks and feels. We say paintings or music are beautiful, but not food. Some philosophers think food should be part of this talk because of modern cooking. But food is eaten and gone, unlike art or music, which lasts. There are also many questions about what we should eat, like organic or vegetarian food. Our choices show our beliefs, and philosophers ask why we choose what we do. Cooking at home and in restaurants is different. Home cooks have a duty to their guests because of love and friendship. In restaurants, cooks have duties to their boss and the food. Their kitchens are for trained people, not everyone. A recent essay talks about how food can help connect different cultures. We can learn about others by enjoying their food and eating together, which has been important in diplomacy. The essay uses fun stories to show this part of food philosophy to readers.'

Text: 'Rob Daviau, from the US, makes special board games called ‘legacy’ games. He thought the board games he played as a child were not fun or challenging anymore. He wondered if board games could have a story. Could choices in one game affect the next game? He changed a classic game called Risk to make Risk Legacy. In this game, choices have a lasting effect. Players might tear up cards or write on the board. The game is played over several sessions, and players remember past actions. Daviau also worked on a legacy version of Pandemic, a popular game where players cure diseases. His next game was SeaFall, set in the age of sail. Players explore new lands. Legacy game designers must think about all player choices to keep the story together. They use testers to see how games work. Jaime Barriga tested SeaFall. He said it takes a lot of time. Sometimes the game works well at first, but later it breaks, and they have to fix it. Legacy games were not expected to be popular. Daviau thought only a few people would like them. But many players, like Russell Chapman, loved them. He thinks they are a big step forward in game design. Ben Hogg, another fan, likes the adventure in these games. He says it’s like watching a new movie each time. Legacy games are like video games and TV shows with episodes. Daviau wanted to write for TV but ended up in game design. He likes telling stories. Pandemic creator Matt Leacock says making a legacy game is like writing a book. You need to know the start and end. Daviau is excited to see what others do with his idea. But he thinks people will soon want something new. Colby Dauch, who works with SeaFall, thinks legacy games change how we see board games.'

Text: 'One night, an octopus named Inky escaped from his tank at New Zealand’s National Aquarium. He moved across the floor and went into a drain that led to the Pacific Ocean. This story was shared a lot online. People like stories about animals escaping, like rats and llamas, because they seem like us. Octopuses are very smart, even though they look very different from us. They can open jars, recognize faces, and use coconut shells as armor. Some people think it is unscientific to say animals are like humans. But Dr. Frans de Waal, who studies animals like gorillas, says it is wrong to ignore the human-like traits of animals. He calls this 'anthropodenial.' He says animals can do many things we thought only humans could do, like thinking about the past and future, showing empathy, and understanding others' motives. In the past, people thought animals were smart. In medieval times, animals could even be put on trial for crimes. Charles Darwin, who created the theory of evolution, said the difference between humans and animals is not big. In the 20th century, people started to see animals as machines that respond to rewards and punishments. But now, de Waal believes we are starting to see animals as smart again. He says we are learning more about animal intelligence. The best tests for animal intelligence consider the animal's special skills. For example, squirrels can remember where they hide nuts, even if they fail human memory tests. In her book, The Soul of an Octopus, Sy Montgomery says if an octopus tested human intelligence, it might think we are not smart because we cannot change our skin color. De Waal is not sure if Inky really found his way to the ocean. But he knows that stories like Inky's help people appreciate animal intelligence. He once did an experiment with monkeys to see if they feel envy. Monkeys given cucumbers got upset when others got grapes, which they liked more. A video of this experiment convinced many people of the findings. This shows how our minds work.'

Text: 'Robots were once only in science fiction books, but now they are becoming very important. Robots have been used in car factories for many years. Now, experts say robots will soon be used in many more jobs, and many countries are not ready for this big change. Many people think robots will do most jobs in the next 50 years, but they also think their own jobs will still be there. This is not true. All job areas will change because of robots. For example, an Australian company made a robot called Hadrian X that can lay 1,000 bricks in one hour. This is much faster than two people can do in a day. In San Francisco, a robot called Tally checks that supermarket shelves are full and prices are correct. People who like robots say they will create new jobs for people who can fix and program them. But some people worry that we will lose important human skills at work. Dr. Jing Bing Zhang, an expert in robotics, studies how robots will change jobs. He says that soon, many robots will be able to work with people safely. In a few years, big companies will have a special manager for robots, and some governments will make new rules for robots. In five years, salaries in the robot industry will go up, but many jobs will not be filled because there are not enough skilled workers. Dr. Zhang says people need to learn new skills because they cannot do the same job forever. New robots will also be made for homes, and they will be very advanced. This is a big chance for companies, but it also means we need new rules to keep us safe. With many jobs at risk, education is important to prepare for the future with robots. Countries need more people studying science, technology, engineering, and maths, known as STEM, to stay competitive.'

Text: George Mallory, a famous mountain climber, was once asked why he wanted to climb Mount Everest. He answered, "Because it's there." Many people wonder why someone would do something so dangerous. Mallory's answer might inspire some people to follow their dreams. It shows that climbing can be about adventure and fun. 

In 1967, a writer named Tejada-Flores wrote an important essay about climbing. He said there are seven different types of climbing, each with its own rules. The way people climb depends on these rules. This idea is now very popular among climbers in the West. Many climbers love climbing because it makes them feel free. But sometimes, climbing can feel limiting, like when a storm keeps you stuck in a tent. This is a bit of a puzzle, but some say that having fewer choices can also feel like freedom.

Another climber, Joe Fitschen, thinks we should ask, "Why do people climb?" He believes climbing is in our nature. We like to take on challenges, even if they are risky. This means climbing is more about our biology than thinking it through.

Brian Treanor, a US academic, wrote that climbing can help us develop important qualities like courage and respect for nature. He thinks these qualities are important in today's world. Climbing can help us live better lives.

Some climbers believe that climbing without help from others or technology is more challenging and deserves more respect. Ebert and Robinson, two expert climbers, said that climbing alone or without extra help is harder and should be recognized more. But this idea can be dangerous because it might encourage risky behavior.

Climbing can also be about being in the moment and focusing on the climb. This is similar to Zen philosophy, which teaches people to find peace. This is another reason why people might be drawn to climbing.

Text: 'For over sixty years, the pianist Alfred Brendel was very important in classical music. He was a serious man who played and recorded many famous European piano pieces. He wrote and played a lot, but he did not teach much. People who knew him well saw he could be fun, but he did not show this in his concerts. He worked hard, always studying, traveling, and performing. 

Then, four or five years ago, a young boy named Kit Armstrong came to one of Brendel’s concerts and asked for lessons. At first, Brendel did not think it was a good idea. He had not taught many students before. He said, ‘You don’t need a mountain guide to teach a child how to walk.’ But there was something special about Kit, who was about 14 years old then. Brendel listened to him play. Kit played very well and from memory. He gave Brendel a CD of a concert he did, and Brendel thought, “I have to make time for him.” Kit’s performance was very special.

As Brendel is retiring, Kit is becoming more known. Brendel is careful because he does not want Kit to get tired too soon. Kit, now 19, is always busy. He learns new languages, studies math, writes computer code, and plays tennis. His mother is always with him. Kit also writes music. Brendel says, ‘Writing music helps you read music better. Kit has a great memory and can read music very well. He listens to his own playing and to me when I teach him. He understands and can do what I say. If I tell him one thing in a piece, he will do it everywhere in the piece.’

Brendel is careful not to make people expect too much from Kit. He says it is not good when newspapers call Kit the future great pianist of the 21st century. It can be harmful. Kit can play some things very well, but he needs more time and experience for others. 

Now, at 80 years old, Brendel is more relaxed. He says, ‘When I was young, I did not want to be famous quickly, but I wanted to do certain things by the age of 50. When I was 50, I did most of those things, but I wanted to do more, so I continued. I do not have the physical strength now, but in my mind, I think about many pieces I never played. I don’t play now, but it’s a nice new part of my life.’'

Text: 'When I was little, I thought gardens were always beautiful places. My Grandad's garden was not in a dirty city. It was next to a river and went down to the water. You couldn't reach the river, but you could hear the water and birds in the trees. I thought all gardens were like this – a place to escape and find peace. Grandad's garden was simple. He didn't have a greenhouse like some neighbors. Their greenhouses were made from old windows. At home, my dad was often quiet. He wasn't boring. He liked funny things and had favorite phrases like 'It's immaterial to me.' He left school without finishing and became a plumber. He didn't love plumbing; it was just his job. He wasn't very ambitious, but once he and Mum thought about moving to Canada. It didn't happen. He was good at fixing things at home. He could make bookshelves or cupboards very well. My parents moved house only once. But my mother liked to change furniture. One day, a piano came to our house. I wanted to like it, but it scared me. I liked the brass candlesticks on it, but my mother took them away. I never got to play the piano. My sister had lessons. When I asked my mother why I didn't, she said, 'You'd never have practised.' I liked the river best. I could imagine another world there. I would take a fishing net and go to the river. I wore old sandals and looked for fish. I tried to keep the fish at home, but it didn't work, so I put them back in the river. I wanted to leave school soon, but it seemed hard. One day, my father said, 'There is a job for an apprentice gardener in the Parks Department. I thought you might like it.' My dad usually wanted me to be a carpenter, but maybe he saw I loved gardening. I like to think he hoped it would be good for me.'

Text: 'Lawrence MacEwen is on his Scottish island, the Isle of Muck. I am with him. A strong wind from the Atlantic Ocean is blowing. It feels like it could push us off the cliff and into the ocean below. MacEwen's sheepdog, Tie, comes close, and MacEwen pets him. The wind is loud, but MacEwen is comfortable on his island. He is showing me around. He points north and shouts, ‘That island is Eigg. The one to the west is the Isle of Rum. It gets more rain than we do.’ I see rain clouds over Rum's mountains. ‘Beyond Rum is the island of Soay.’ Suddenly, MacEwen says, ‘I have sheep to move,’ as rain comes closer. We walk down the hill. As we walk, he tells me about the island: Muck is three km long and half as wide; its geese eat a lot of grass; and the MacEwens have lived here for 3000 years. Moving the sheep stops our talk. Tie, the sheepdog, is trying to move the sheep but is not doing well. ‘Away to me, Tie. Away to me,’ MacEwen says, meaning the dog should go right. Tie goes straight into the sheep, causing confusion. ‘Tie,’ MacEwen says, sounding disappointed. ‘That will never do.’ The dog looks sorry. The Isle of Muck is mostly run by the MacEwen family. Lawrence runs the farm with his wife, Jenny; their son Colin manages the island cottages; and their daughter Mary runs the island hotel, Port Mor, with her husband, Toby. Mary and Toby like that their two boys can explore the island and sail small boats in summer. ‘They leave the house and come back when they’re hungry.’ But island life has challenges. Electricity is only available sometimes. On my first evening, I wait for the lights to turn on. The next morning, Mary makes breakfast with a flashlight. I get used to it, along with no mobile phone service. ‘There is mobile reception on the hill,’ Mary says. ‘Most people last a couple of days, then put the phone away.’ So I do too. Everything on Muck feels surprising. The boat today brings groceries and three musicians with instruments. Their concert in the island’s tearoom is a big success, with people tapping their feet to the music. That night, by a warm fire, Lawrence MacEwen tells me how he met his wife, Jenny. ‘Her father bought a small farm on the isle of Soay from a newspaper ad. He had never been to Scotland. Jenny was sent to manage it.’ Did Jenny know about farming? ‘She was good at typing.’ I go to bed with rain and wake up to more rain. But I eat well, with almost all the food from the island. Mary sends me to fisherman Sandy Mathers for fresh fish. I bring it back to Mary at the kitchen door. By 7 pm, our fish is on the table, very tasty. Also uncertain: my ferry ride the next morning to another island. Many ferries were canceled in the last two months because of high seas. If my ferry doesn’t come, I will stay on Muck for two more days. Now, with or without a phone, I secretly hope for that.'

Text: 'At first, the game design industry was mostly for computer scientists and people who taught themselves. It was not easy to enter. People often thought video games were just a hobby for young people. But now, the video games industry is serious business. Experts are not surprised. Making video games is hard. When a new movie comes out, video games about it need many team members and months of hard work. Like many jobs, it is hard to get into, but it is growing. Jim Donelly, who works for an online games magazine, says: ‘It’s hard to make progress in big companies or to change big games. But the industry needs game designers more than ever. Not just the leaders, but also the people who design parts of the game.’ How can you join this industry? Many companies want people with a computer science degree, but Jim thinks differently. ‘The only way is to make games. The tools are there. You need to make something to get a job. Game design is more than a job; it is a way of life. Like any creative work, you must do it to make it real.’ Another expert, John Field, has other ideas. ‘Just doing it is good, but it’s more complex. Many want to work in games, but few meet the industry’s needs. Even fewer have the talent, skills, and vision to help the industry grow.’ Can you do it alone? ‘Maybe, but it’s hard,’ says John. ‘A good course in games can help and give support. Most game designers start as programmers or artists and move up. They like all kinds of entertainment and arts. They may have worked a few years after school and decided games are for them. They are not just fans; they are interested in the future of games. Connections can help too. To get ahead, you need to network.’ The idea of a young boy playing games all day is old. Now, games are for everyone. Families play on consoles. Smartphones have many new games through apps and social media. John thinks there is room to grow. ‘Games are for more people now. They are also a great way to learn. I see many new chances and opportunities.’

Text: 'Since I was a child, I have always wanted to play football. My dad encouraged me to play, but he didn't force me. I had a friend whose dad was very pushy. He always told my friend what he couldn't do. My friend stopped playing football because of this. I am glad my dad was different. When I score a goal from far away, people say it's just luck, but it's not. I have practiced shooting from a distance since I was a kid. The best players practice a lot, even if they have natural talent. Sometimes young players crash into each other, but I learned technique. When I teach kids, I tell them to enjoy learning skills. At school, I played many sports like rounders, baseball, athletics, and basketball. I know education is important, but football was all I thought about then. My teachers did a good job, but I didn't notice it at the time. I don't want it to be like that for my son. We try to read him books, but he is too young to sit still. He likes to kick the books around, like me. At the start of my football career, the manager helped young players like me join the first team. He didn't make a big deal about it, but we knew it was our chance. I scored in the first game of the season, but we lost. A TV presenter said, 'You can't win anything with kids.' That made us realize we had to work hard. I rely on my close friends and family. Having a lot of money can cause problems. People say, 'I can't believe you let your mother keep working.' I have helped my parents with money. I paid off their house loan and bought them a car. My family is strong and would not want to be on my payroll. My mum loves her job as a hairdresser. I like to use my money to help people around me. I have a lot of money, but not as much as people think. After I stop playing football, I want to take a year off. I want to go skiing, but I can't now because if I break a leg, I can't play football and won't be insured.'

Text: 'We were living at Reef Point because of Sam Carter. Sam was my father’s agent in Los Angeles. He helped us find a cheap place to live because my father could not write in Los Angeles. Sam was worried about losing money. In the summer, the beach was empty because sea fogs covered the sun. Reef Point was not popular with visitors. The road was not good, and the nice resort of La Carmella was close by. People with money stayed there. Only people with little money or those who loved surfing came to Reef Point. But now, with the hot weather, many people came. After months alone, we were now surrounded by people and activities. My father was busy writing a script and was in a bad mood. I often went to the beach with a book and my dog, Rusty. We did not have a dog when we moved to Reef Point, but Rusty chose us. I tried to chase him away, but he stayed. I gave him water, and my father pretended to be angry but was not serious. Rusty loved the beach and brought me things he found. Sometimes he brought things that were not his, like a new shoe or a towel, and I had to return them. Rusty liked to swim with me, even though I was faster. He never got tired. That day, my father went to Los Angeles to deliver his script. Rusty and I spent the afternoon swimming. As the sun set, we watched the surfers. One surfer was very good. She finished surfing and came over to me. She asked why I didn’t join them. I said I didn’t have a surfboard and no money to buy one. She asked if I was British and visiting. I said I lived here and my father came to write a film script. She asked his name, and I said Rufus Marsh. She knew his book, Tall as the Morning, and was interested in me after that.'

Violet Hetherington was in a long line at the dock in Southampton. She was waiting to get on the ship, Queen Caroline. Her friend Annie had told her to arrive late, but this was bad advice. There was a problem with the computer system, and everyone was upset. People had paid a lot of money for this trip, and now they were waiting for a long time. Violet wanted to leave, but she realized she lost her phone. This was more annoying than the long line. She couldn't call the taxi company to check if she left her phone there because all her numbers were in the phone. Her son Harry always told her to be careful about this. 

Violet asked a couple behind her if she could use their phone. She called Harry and left a message, asking him to ask her neighbor Kristina to look for her phone. If the phone was not in her apartment, she would have trouble because she needed the numbers in New York. Part of her was relieved, but she didn't tell Harry. Harry thought he was wiser than his mother. Her younger son, Daniel, was more understanding because he was forgetful too. 

Finally, the line started moving, and Violet gave her travel documents to go on the ship. She felt worse when she saw the ship's foyer. It looked like a hotel that tried too hard to be fancy. There were fake wood panels, shiny chandeliers, and carpets like those in airports. Violet went to the elevators, which were full of tired passengers. She was squished in the lift, but finally, she got out on the twelfth floor. Her room had the balcony she wanted. She was ready to complain if it didn't. She had paid a lot to make sure she could see the sea.

Text: John Maloof bought a box of old photo negatives at an auction. He did not know he was discovering the mystery of Vivian Maier. Maloof wanted pictures for a book about Portage Park in Chicago, USA. Instead, he found 30,000 images by Maier, a street photographer. Maloof now has many of Maier’s things: her cameras, 2,000 rolls of film, 3,000 prints, 100,000 negatives, and many movies and audiotapes. Maloof feels lucky. He said, ‘When I bought this, I didn’t know what it was. I could have sold it all.’ Maloof and his friend Anthony Rydzon are learning about Maier’s life. They talked to families she worked for as a nanny and people from the shop where she developed film. Maier was born in 1926 in New York and grew up in France. She came back to New York in 1951 and moved to Chicago in 1956 to work as a nanny. Maier was private and always had a camera. She wore big coats, hats, and strong shoes. Maren Baylaender, whose husband hired Maier, said, ‘On her day off, she had her camera and came back late at night. She was private but had strong opinions about movies and politics.’ Maier knew a lot about theatre and movies. She was not very social but liked to take pictures and talk to people. She loved her ‘second job’ of taking pictures. Rydzon said, ‘She was a true artist and did what she wanted.’ Maier’s work was not for money. Her photos often showed women, children, the old, and the poor. Photography expert Larry Silverman finds her pictures interesting. He wonders if she made her own style or copied others. Maloof wonders if he will see all the negatives. He did not care about photography before Maier’s work. Her pictures inspired him to take his own. Maloof said, ‘Her work is about people and street scenes. It is more important than I thought. We want to make her name known and put Vivian Maier in history books.’

Text: 'When a novel is called ambitious, it often means it didn't fully succeed. But this is not true for Eleanor Catton’s book, The Luminaries. I talked to her in the UK when her book was very popular. She was calm, even though she was still in her twenties. She had just come from Germany and was going back to New Zealand the next day. She told me a story about being stopped at passport control and asked to prove she was a writer. She showed her book. The officer asked, ‘What’s it about?’ This is not an easy question for an author. The Luminaries is set in the 1860s in New Zealand. There are many crimes, and 12 men meet to solve them. The story becomes very complex. Catton said she wanted to write a murder mystery, not a historical novel, but found the past gave more chances for problems for her characters. The book is over 800 pages long because she wanted to give each of the 20 main characters enough attention. When I ask how it feels to be successful at a young age, she says, ‘It’s nice coming from a small country because everyone feels the success is partly theirs. There’s a family feeling at home, and I got a lot of support from other people’s grandmas.’ Then she adds, ‘What is annoying is when people think I’m not trying to do something philosophical in the book.’ ‘I wanted to write the book in the shape of a spiral. Each part is half the length of the one before,’ said Catton. It gets faster as it goes. I ask if it matters if the reader notices this. ‘I wanted to create a book with patterns that didn’t matter, but if you cared, you could see them.’ Even with its unusual structure, The Luminaries is an exciting murder mystery. Surprisingly, she says she didn’t plan the story beforehand. ‘I would write myself into a corner and then see how I could get out of it.’ She also wanted the book to be fun for the reader. We also talk about her love of TV drama series. I ask if she might like to write for TV. ‘That could be cool,’ she says. She talks with enthusiasm and laughs quietly. She is excited when talking about her work and New Zealand. ‘I notice when I come to Britain how my imagination changes just by being in a different place. I see why writers move away from New Zealand to busy places, to be around many people.’ But for now, New Zealand will stay her home. I hope it gives her ideas for more novels.'

Text: 'When Jonny Kinkead was a boy, he liked to make things in his dad’s garage and play the guitar. For the last forty years, he has been making guitars by hand. ‘I still love the guitar,’ he says. ‘It’s amazing how two pieces of wood can make a beautiful sound. Using different wood makes different sounds. It still surprises me.’ Jonny learned to play his brother’s guitar at eleven. At sixteen, he wanted a bass guitar. ‘Some people would get a job and save money to buy one,’ he says. ‘But I wanted to make it myself. I studied guitars and learned how different shapes and wood types changed the sound.’ The bass was the first instrument Jonny made, but he and his brothers had made other things before. ‘We made model boats and planes, so I knew how to build things. My father taught us to use tools. I also fixed instruments for my friends.’ Jonny’s bass guitar was good, but he didn’t think about making guitars as a job. ‘I also liked painting and sculpture,’ he says. After school, he studied architecture at university. ‘Architecture is about design, which I liked, and being an architect seemed like a good job,’ he remembers. But he left the course halfway through. ‘I was too independent,’ he says. ‘But I realized I wanted to make guitars. It’s like sculpture because you shape sound. And it’s more practical than art because people use guitars.’ Since then, Jonny has made guitars for a living. For the first ten years, he also cleaned windows part-time. At first, he sold guitars for the cost of the materials, but as he became known as a good guitar-maker, he could charge more. Even now, almost forty years later, Jonny says he is ‘still just making a living’. He can only make ten guitars a year, which limits his earnings. In the early years, he worked hard to become known. He went to music festivals and asked musicians to try his guitars and tell their friends. He also learned how to price his guitars. Jonny thinks it’s easier for new guitar-makers in the UK today. ‘When I started, people thought the best guitars were from the USA,’ he says. ‘UK guitars weren’t seen as good, even though we have good courses and skills here. But now, UK hand-made guitars are respected.’ Jonny says you can learn important skills in classes, and new guitar-makers should take courses. But he also believes in learning by trying. ‘Look at other instruments, see what works or doesn’t, and try different things,’ Jonny says. ‘If you make the back too thin or thick, it won’t sound good. If someone teaches you, you learn one way, but if you teach yourself, like I did, you learn everything.’'

Text: 'When English people talk, they often start with the weather. This is a tradition. A famous writer, Dr Johnson, said, ‘When two Englishmen meet, their first talk is of the weather’. This was true 200 years ago and is still true today. Many people think English people talk about the weather because they are interested in it. But this is not true. The American writer Bill Bryson says the English weather is not exciting. There are no tornadoes or big storms. The English broadcaster Jeremy Paxman says the weather is interesting because it is always changing. My research shows that both are wrong. English people talk about the weather to start conversations. It is a way to be friendly. When someone says, ‘Nice day, isn’t it?’, they are not really talking about the weather. They are just starting a conversation. This is like monkeys grooming each other to be social. There are three times when English people use weather talk: as a greeting, to start a conversation, or when there is nothing else to say. This makes it seem like English people talk about the weather a lot. But really, it is just a way to talk to each other.'

Alice Leader was standing in front of Hadrian’s Wall in Britain. She was trying to tell her class of 12- and 13-year-olds about how amazing it was that the Romans built a wall 120 km long and 5 meters high about 1900 years ago. The students were interested because they chose this trip over trips to Spain, Greece, or France. But they wanted to know why the wall was built, and Alice felt her answers were not good enough. She could not find a good historical novel about life at the Wall in Roman times, so she decided to write one herself. After teaching for 31 years, Alice started writing books in 2001. She said teaching is like acting and is very tiring, but writing is exciting and not as exhausting. Her old teaching friends are jealous because she still connects with children through her books. Alice wants her books to be different from other children's books, which are often about bad experiences or total fantasy like Harry Potter. She always taught English and History together and loves making bored children interested. Writing is like teaching for her. She started writing her first novel because there were not enough books like it, and because her two sons were leaving home. Her head teacher suggested she take a creative writing course, which surprised her. She didn’t want to do it at first, but she had to send a story to join the course. She quickly wrote a story about a Roman couple and their baby. The course students liked her story and said she should publish it. With only school report cards as proof of her writing, she asked for a year off to write her first book. Her husband, Zachary Leader, is a critic and editor, and he helped her a lot. Alice says they work well together. He helps her improve her writing by changing sentences and suggesting new words. Alice likes to add more scenes to her stories.

Text: 'To raise money for charity, a newspaper and a TV company asked brothers Jonny and Alistair Brownlee, who are champion triathletes, to join a special race. The race was between a man and a car, and also between the two brothers. In the Yorkshire Dales in northern England, Jonny and his younger brother Ali would race to the same place. Jonny would drive a car on the roads, and Ali would ride a mountain bike across the countryside. ‘I’m looking forward to it,’ Jonny said at the start line. ‘I’ve never done anything like this before: it’s exciting! These roads have beautiful views – and it’s very cold now, so I’ll be warm in the car.’ Alistair was also excited. He wore full winter cycling clothes, while Jonny wore jeans and a sweatshirt. Alistair said, ‘I’ve seen his driving before, so I’m not sure he’s even going to make it. I might just stop for a cup of tea halfway up.’ The race started at Semerwater lake in Wensleydale and finished at Fleet Moss, Yorkshire’s highest road, 350 metres up. It was easy for the car, but Alistair had to climb a steep hill at the start. After a quick handshake, they began. Alistair rode his bike up the hill and across the countryside to Fleet Moss. Jonny got in the car and drove on the road. They would see each other again at the finish line. The question was, who would get there first? Jonny’s confidence dropped quickly. Just 15 seconds into the drive, he met a big tractor on the road. ‘Welcome to Yorkshire,’ he said to the cameraman in his car. ‘If Alistair beats me, it’s because of this farmer!’ After the tractor moved, Jonny continued driving. Alistair was having a hard time with the hill. He had to get off his bike and carry it up the hill, past walls and over fences. Sheep watched him as he walked with the bike on his shoulders. Finally, he reached the top. On the other side, the ground was open, and the sun was shining. Alistair started to go faster. In the car, Jonny faced another problem. The roads in the villages were very narrow. He had to drive slowly and carefully. After the last village, the road was straight to the finish line. Neither brother knew where the other was. As Jonny drove fast to Fleet Moss, Alistair was riding across his last field and back on the road. He reached the finish line and stopped. Alistair looked up and asked the crowd, ‘Is he here?’ They said no. Alistair was happy. A few minutes later, Jonny arrived. ‘Well done,’ Jonny said sadly. ‘I’m disappointed.’'

Text: 'When you play on Centre Court at Wimbledon, the silence is what you notice first. You bounce the ball on the soft grass; you toss it up to serve; you hit it and hear the sound of your shot. The grass, the history, the old stadium, the players in white, and the quiet crowd make you feel like you are in a different world. The silence helps me focus on my game. During a match, I try to think only about the game and the point I am playing. When a point is over, the silence breaks with applause and cheers. I hear them, but they seem far away. I don’t think about the fifteen thousand people watching me in the arena or the millions watching on TV as I play Roger Federer in the 2008 Wimbledon final – the biggest match of my life. I always dreamed of playing at Wimbledon. My uncle Toni, my coach, always told me it was the most important tournament. By age 14, I was telling my friends I would play there and win. Before 2008, I played and lost to Federer twice – in the final the year before and the year before that. Losing in 2006 was not so bad. I was happy to be there at age twenty. Federer beat me easily because I didn’t believe I could win. But losing in 2007 was very hard. I knew I could have played better. It was not my skills that failed, but my mind. I cried for half an hour after that loss. Losing hurts more when you have a chance to win. Toni, who is a tough coach, usually criticizes me even when I win. But after that loss, he told me not to cry and that there would be more chances. I told him he didn’t understand, that it was my last chance to win. I know a professional athlete’s career is short, and I want to make the most of it. Some moments are more important than others, and I missed a big one in 2007. But Toni was right. I had another chance in 2008. I was sure I learned from my loss the year before. I believed I would win. The night before the final, I had dinner with family and friends. We didn’t talk about the match. They knew I was already thinking about it in my mind. Until the match started, that space in my mind was mine alone.'

Text: 'A young Englishwoman named Jane Goodall went to Africa in April 1957. She wrote to her family, "I am living in the Africa I have always dreamed of." Jane spent most of her life in Africa. She became a citizen, journalist, scientist, activist, and environmentalist there. In 1963, Britain's National Geographical Society made Jane Goodall famous with articles and TV shows about her work with chimpanzees. She also wrote books for children and adults, like the 1971 bestseller "In the Shadow of Man," which is in 47 languages. Jane Goodall is one of the most famous female scientists of the 20th century. Some people think her fame hides her real work. Many stories about her life are not complete. They show her as a girl who loved adventure, a woman who wanted to live with wild animals, and a feminist. But these stories do not show her true achievements. Jane Goodall's research is very important. She helped us understand chimpanzees' social and emotional lives. Before her work, people did not know chimpanzees ate meat or used tools. We also did not know they have emotions and social systems like humans. Her book, "The Chimpanzees of Gombe" (1986), is a key work in chimpanzee research. Her study in Gombe, Nigeria, is called one of the great scientific achievements. Jane Goodall changed how we study animals and how we think about ourselves. Even as a child, Jane showed signs of her future. When she was five, she disappeared one day. The police and neighbors looked for her. She came back with straw in her hair. She had hidden in a henhouse to see how hens lay eggs. This was the start of her career as a biologist.'

Text: 'During our first conversation, Shirley Ford talks to me in different voices. She sounds like a cheeky 8-year-old boy, a tired mother, a funny old Scottish woman, and a fast-talking alien. Her voices are known to people who watch children's TV and cartoons, and to those who have seen computer programs about health and safety. ‘I’ve just done a voiceover about back injuries,’ she says, ‘so I had to learn how to say many medical words.’ Shirley talks about what it takes to do voiceovers. ‘Many actors think they can do funny voices, and many of them can,’ she says. ‘But there’s more to it. You have to make the script come alive for people who can’t see you. Many famous people want to do voiceover work. Producers invite them to auditions, but often they don’t get parts because they are used to acting with their whole bodies.’ After school, Shirley took a drama course to become a regular actor. During the course, she sometimes sang jingles for TV adverts. ‘One day,’ she says, ‘the man at the recording studio asked me to try out for the part of a rabbit in a cartoon. It seemed silly – I hadn’t studied drama to play rabbits – but I tried it for fun and got a big part.’ Shirley realized she could do voices and that voiceover work might be her path. ‘Things just happened for me,’ she says. ‘In my second film, I played the main character – and her brother and mother.’ Adult female actors often do voices for small boys and girls. Their voices are lighter than male actors, and hiring child performers is complicated, which production companies want to avoid. Shirley has learned to make the right sounds and collects new voices by watching children’s TV. Cartoons are the best part of a job that includes educational videos and vacuum cleaner adverts. ‘Those are hard because you have to sound excited about something you don’t care about, but my years in this job help,’ she says. ‘The trick is to smile while you're talking – that makes your voice sound happy. When I do animation work, it feels like a holiday; working with other actors makes a big difference.’ The competition for work is tough, and a good showreel – a recording showing what the artist can do – is important. ‘It’s worth investing in a strong showreel,’ Shirley says. ‘There are agencies that help voiceover artists make them.’ She says she got where she is – near the top of her job – through hard work as much as talent. ‘Whether it’s making your showreel and taking it to film and TV companies, advertising agencies, and recording studios, or just practising your voices, it’s about setting goals and not giving up.’ For anyone thinking about a career in voiceovers, Shirley suggests attending ‘specialist workshops – they cover all types of voiceover.’ She also believes loving human sound is important, describing herself as obsessed with voices and becoming the characters she performs. ‘If I’ve been doing a certain kind of American voice, for example, it can take over me and I’ll speak like that for hours, maybe even days,’ she says. ‘My children are used to their mum talking in different voices.’'

Text: 'People often ask me how I became a cartoonist. This makes sense because cartooning is a job many kids dream about, like being a race car driver. But most people stop dreaming about these jobs and think about more realistic ones, like being a lawyer or making car parts. The idea that you can make money by drawing doodles like the ones in school notebooks seems silly. But some people do it. People become cartoonists in different ways, but most have wanted to do it for a long time. For me, I loved comic strips as a child, drew for school papers, and was known as ‘the kid who draws’. I studied graphic design in college and showed my drawings to different companies after I graduated. I was lucky to find a newspaper that needed political cartoons. I drew some ideas, they bought them, and soon I was making enough money to live on. You don’t need much to be a cartoonist. You don’t need a university degree, a lot of money, or even to be very good at drawing. You just need your brain, your hand, and something to draw with. But if it were that easy, there would be as many cartoonists as teachers. Being a cartoonist is hard. You shouldn’t try it unless you feel you can’t do anything else. It’s easier to get a regular job that pays the rent and gives you time for family and hobbies. The more skills you have, the better your chances of making a living with your art. I’ve done political cartoons, comic strips, and comic books. I’ve also been a writer, a caricaturist, and sometimes a designer. I don’t say no to any work because you can learn a lot from jobs you don’t really want to do. It helps to be smart, read a lot, and be curious about everything. What about the business side of being a cartoonist? In the past, many cartoonists could find regular jobs at newspapers and magazines. But now, cartooning is more like running your own business. You have to make and sell your work. Cartoonists with good business skills often do better than those who are very artistic but not good at business. I often meet people who have never sold a cartoon but are afraid someone will steal their ideas. Some are so worried they don’t let others see their work! To protect your work, just draw a little ‘c’ for ‘copyright’, put a circle around it, and write your name and the date. But it’s more likely that no one will be interested in your work. If someone does steal a cartoon and it becomes popular online, it’s not a disaster – it can be a lucky break!'

Text: 'Twenty years ago, I was moving to a new house and cleaning out old things. I decided to throw away an electric guitar that my dad gave me for my 16th birthday. It was a black, Japanese-made guitar. I usually don't like to throw things away, so why did I want to throw this guitar away? I took it to the rubbish dump. A young man saw me and asked, ‘You’re not going to throw that away, are you?’ I said yes, and he asked if he could have it. I said ‘Yes’, and we went our separate ways. After that, I felt sad about what I did. A few months ago, I got an email that changed my life. It was from a man named Keith Rushton, who fixes guitars. He said, ‘I’ve got your electric guitar.’ The guitar had been sold many times since I gave it away. Keith found my name and address on the back of the guitar. He used my name to find me online and contacted me through the newspaper I work for. He wanted to sell it back to me. I was so happy. I would have paid him anything, but his price was fair. My dad used to put name-and-address stickers on everything, even my guitar. My parents wanted me to learn the classical guitar in the 1970s because it was popular. I liked the sound, but I couldn’t learn well. So, I switched to the electric guitar. It was also the time of punk music, where you didn’t have to play well to be a rock star. When I got my guitar back from Keith, I remembered my birthday in 1978 when my parents gave it to me. The guitar felt smooth and smaller than I remembered. I played it again, and my fingers remembered the chords. The electric guitar is not really for playing alone. Now, I want to form a band. My son is learning the saxophone, so maybe we can play together. Or maybe I can find other people like me and we can call ourselves ‘The Regainers’!'

Text: 'People are talking a lot about sleep these days. When I wrote the book Insomniac, about people who can't sleep, I felt like I was the only one saying how bad it is not to sleep. Not sleeping affects our minds, bodies, and moods. People who can't sleep know how important sleep is. It's good that sleep is getting attention now. But what about dreams? I don't hear much about dreams. We lose dreams when we wake up early. The last hour or two of sleep is when we dream the most. This is called REM or 'Rapid Eye Movement' sleep. Our most vivid and emotional dreams happen in REM sleep, just before we wake up. A good sleeper spends about a quarter of their sleep in REM. If someone lives 90 years, they will spend six or seven years in REM. When people don't get REM sleep, they have more REM the next night. This shows dreams are important. In 1953, researchers found REM sleep. Many agreed with Sigmund Freud, a famous psychologist, who said dreams help us understand our minds. But later studies did not support this. Now, dream studies focus more on the physical side of dreams. There is not much agreement among dream researchers, says Robert Stickgold, a sleep scientist at Harvard University. Dreams are important. At a meeting, P.F. Pagel from the University of Colorado Medical School talked about a study. It showed that actors, writers, and directors remember and use dreams better than other people. He thinks people who are interested in creativity use dreams more. It makes sense that filmmakers have a strong connection with dreams because films are like dreams. But I wonder, are only artistic people using their dreams? Don't teachers, software designers, and politicians also need to think creatively? Stickgold says dreams help us think in new ways. They help us find new patterns and ideas. For example, when people wake up from REM sleep and are asked to say what they think of a word, their answers are more original. They put together ideas in surprising ways. This is creativity, says Stickgold. I write better after intense dreams. Even a bad dream helps me think. On those days, words and ideas come quickly. I don't know why, but it works. Creativity is not just for writers or artists. We all live in a complex world. We need our brains to work well. We need to think creatively in our relationships with others. This is why we need to dream.'

Text: 'Twenty years ago, Susie Ray left London and moved to a small town by the sea in south-west England. In her studio, you can see the sea from the window. There are empty frames on the walls and photos of her two daughters. Susie is a famous copyist artist. She can paint like famous artists from the past, like Monet and Van Gogh. Her copies look so real that even art experts think they are the originals. The real paintings are worth millions, but Susie’s copies sell for a few hundred to £12,000, depending on how long she works on them. Susie’s clients include galleries and private collectors. Some collectors like to show off her copies as if they are real. One famous person says he has a ‘Van Gogh’ painting, but it is really a ‘Susie Ray Van Gogh’. Some people keep the real painting in a bank and hang Susie’s copy at home. Susie is honest about her work. She signs her name on the back of the canvas. It is illegal to sell a copy as the real thing, and Susie does not do that. She knows people who have, but they often get into trouble. Susie was not always a copyist. After her art degree, she worked as an illustrator for a botanical garden. She did not earn much money, but it helped her learn to be accurate. Now, she tells young artists to learn to draw well. Susie has studied a lot to do her work. She can draw plants, make copies of old paintings, and reproduce modern art. She likes French impressionists like Manet, Cezanne, and Degas. Some people think modern art is easy, but Susie says it is not. The impressionists painted quickly but carefully, and that is hard to do. Susie does not paint her own original art. She says her work is the result of years of training, and she earns a good living from it. She tried painting her own things once, like fishing nets, but they looked like photos. Susie is a perfectionist.'

Ellen MacArthur loved the sea and wanted to be the fastest sailor. From a young age, she was obsessed with sailing. She felt a strong connection with her boats, and they worked together as one. When she was on land, she found everyday life boring and wanted to return to the ocean. After coming second in the Vendée Globe, a solo round-the-world race, she showed me her small boat, Kingfisher. It was her home for 94 days. She planned everything carefully, even counting how many rolls of kitchen paper she needed. She showed me her freeze-dried food, small gas stove, and medical supplies. Her boat was her world, and she took care of it because her life depended on it.

Now, Ellen sees the world like a boat. She thinks it is small and beautiful, but its supplies are running out. Her view changed after a trip to South Georgia, an island in the south Atlantic. There, she helped with a bird survey and saw many old whaling stations. This made her think about how we take what we want and move on. When I visited Ellen’s office, she explained why we must act now to save the planet. She said, "No one is making coal, oil, or gas anymore. We have to find a way not to use them up." She now talks about re-using things, like industrial carpet tiles. For the last three years, she has visited factories and talked to people about using fewer non-renewable resources. She started the Ellen MacArthur Foundation, a charity that helps young people think about a sustainable future.

Ellen misses the adventure of being at sea. She says it made her who she is. At sea, she was focused on the record and survival. Her new message is not as simple as being the fastest sailor, but it is more important. She believes this work is the most important thing she has ever done.

Text: 'Jordan Romero is 13 years old and wants to be the youngest person to climb Mount Everest. If he does it, he could become very famous. Many young people spend a lot of time on computers and games, but Jordan wants to inspire kids to go outside. Jordan's team includes his father, Paul, and mother, Karen.
