They call themselves 'Team Romero'. Climbing Everest is only part of their goal. If Jordan climbs Everest and Vinson Massif in Antarctica, he will be the youngest person to climb the Seven Summits, the highest mountains on each continent. Not many people do this before they are thirty. Jordan has already climbed five of them and might finish before he turns 20. Some famous climbers think it is not a good idea for a 13-year-old to climb Everest. They say a young climber might be strong, but they worry if a teenager is emotionally ready. They also think a young person might not have enough experience to make good decisions while climbing. The Romeros know about these opinions. Paul says, 'I know people criticize us, but I can't worry about it. We have a lot to do. Karen and I think about the risks, but we believe our experience will help. Watching Jordan grow gives me confidence. He is becoming strong and mature.' I also wonder why Jordan wants to do this. Is it because his father loves adventure? Paul says, 'This is not about me becoming famous for my son's achievements. At first, Jordan wanted to do it later, but we thought: 'Why not now?' We talk to him to make sure he still wants to do it.' When I ask Jordan what he likes about the challenge, he says, 'I just focus on my goal.' In the past, few people cared about being the youngest or fastest to climb a mountain. Now, every adventure is shared online, and every climb becomes a record challenge. The more exciting the record, the more people are interested. This is a problem for Jordan. We might say that achievement is more important than enjoyment, but if Jordan wants to inspire others, he has to share his story. This means blogging, taking photos, and giving interviews. He has to do something amazing, like climbing Everest. 'And you know what?' Paul says. 'If Jordan decides he wants to stop climbing and play basketball instead, we will stop this project and go to the gym.''

Text: 'When you see a teenager with an MP3 player, it’s probably not classical music they’re listening to. Most people can name many pop groups, but if you ask my friends about Brahms, they don’t know who he is. I am studying music at university, but my classmates don’t know much about classical music either. If you don’t know who wrote the music, you probably don’t have their recordings. The numbers are not good for classical music fans. Only 3% of concert tickets sold last year were for classical music, and the average classical CD sells only 300 copies. I find that hard to believe. Why is there less interest in classical music, which has been around for centuries? Older people blame TV and video games, but I don’t think that’s the reason. The truth is, classical music doesn’t attract most people, especially teenagers, who buy most music and concert tickets. I know some teenagers who go to classical concerts, but they are few. I play in an orchestra, but I’m not a big classical music fan. I like many styles, but I don’t listen to much classical music. So why don’t teenagers like classical music? First, the pace and rhythm of classical music, with its many mood changes, are difficult for us. We like to talk fast, play fast, and think fast. Experts say we can’t pay attention for more than about three minutes, which is too short for most classical pieces but perfect for a pop song. Pop music is simple and easy to listen to, while classical music needs time and focus. Pop music topics are more interesting to teenagers than long classical pieces with no words. The way we listen to music has changed. In the past, families played music together at home, and playing an instrument was important. The only other way to hear music was at a concert. Now, you can find any music online, but we rarely listen to classical music. When did you last hear classical music in a shop? One of my teachers says more people go to classical concerts now, but I bet not many are teenagers. In my orchestra, we play classical music in many places, but I mostly see older people in the audience. I don’t know why more people like classical concerts when they are older, but if you’re a teenager and your parents like something, you probably won’t. Some say schools are to blame for teenagers not liking classical music, but many kids want to play in their school orchestra. They come early to practice and stay after school to rehearse. They like classical music when they play it, but it’s not their favorite music. When we relax, we listen to pop music.'

Bonnie Wyndham got out of her mother’s car and looked at Almonside School. "I’ll make you sorry I’ve come here," she said quietly. Her mother was getting out of the car too, but she didn’t hear Bonnie. Mrs. Wyndham looked around. Almonside was a strange school, with buildings hidden among trees on a hillside. It was confusing at first. Then she saw signs: Science block, gymnasium, riding centre. "Riding centre," said Bonnie, suddenly interested. "Headmaster’s study," said her mother. "This way." Bonnie followed her mother along a wide path between trees. "I wish you’d walk beside me," said Mrs. Wyndham tiredly, but she didn’t expect Bonnie to do so. A few minutes later, her mother was talking to Bonnie’s new headmaster in his office, while Bonnie waited outside. Suddenly, Bonnie stood up. "Why should I just sit here?" she thought. "I’ll be in trouble soon anyway," she thought, "so why not start now?" She left the building and went to the riding centre. There was an old building for the horses and a large place for indoor riding. Bonnie looked around, but no one was there. She was careful as she went to the horses. Bonnie respected horses. The horses were well cared for, she could see that. Almost every stall had a horse, and she looked at each one. "I know what they’re doing here," she told a small pony, touching its nose. The next horse surprised her. "Aren’t you the best!" she said. He was brown with some white. He looked lively, but Bonnie liked that. "I feel like we’ve met before," said Bonnie, petting his neck. "In my dreams, I was riding you in a big competition." His name was Maverick. She wanted to ride him. "I wonder where I can find a bridle and a saddle," she thought. The room with the riding equipment was unlocked. Bonnie was happy. She put a saddle on Maverick and forgot about her mother and the headmaster. When she sat on the big horse outside, she felt like a queen. Her nickname at her old school was Queen Bee, and she laughed. "You’re the best horse I’ve ever ridden, Maverick," she said. "I know about horses, even if I don’t know about other things." She made him walk, then trot. "If I stay here, we could be great friends," she said. She rode around the paddock. The rhythm was exciting, and the breeze felt good on her face. She could tell Maverick trusted her, and she felt sure he’d jump well.

Cody Simpson is a 15-year-old Australian singer. He is known for his quiet confidence. Cody has released many successful songs. But how did he become famous? Cody started playing the guitar when he was six and wrote his first song at seven. He loved swimming and surfing. When he was 13, he posted videos online of himself singing. These videos became very popular. Fans wanted more, so Cody shared more videos. 

Cody was also a talented swimmer. He trained with top coaches. But then, music companies noticed him. Cody had to choose between swimming in Australia or moving to the US for music. He decided to move with his family to the US. It was a hard choice for him. He had to tell his swimming coach and friends about his decision. 

Cody's family supports him but stays out of the spotlight. He thinks it's important to have good people around you. Sometimes, Cody worries about how his decision affects his younger brother and sister. His brother is eight and travels a lot, doing school on the road. But his family always supports him.

Cody believes success comes from taking chances, even if it's scary. He is happy to visit new countries and perform for many fans. But he knows it won't last forever.

Text: 'I jumped out of bed, moved the bedroom curtain, and looked at the river. A new crack in the ice shone in the morning sun. I looked at the sandbags that protect the buildings from flooding when the ice melts. My back still hurt from lifting them. Last week, I worked with many people from the town for long hours. I wanted to show I could do it. But my grandfather didn’t notice much. I looked at the black water from the factory in Milltown. There was ice on both sides, and then solid ice downstream. I took off my pyjamas and put on my kayaking wetsuit. I saw a boy on the other side of the river. I didn’t know him. He was trying to walk on the ice near the warm water from the factory. I put on my kayaking jacket and checked the pocket for my lucky chain. My famous grandfather brought it from South America. Only he, my mom, and I know about it. I also have his diary from that trip. I keep it under my pillow and read it before I sleep. I touched the chain and went to the kitchen. ‘Morning, Rex.’ Mom smiled as I took a banana. ‘You’re up early for a Saturday. I’ll make brunch after your training. Be careful.’ ‘Thanks, Mom.’ I walked down the hall and almost bumped into Grandpa. ‘Watch where you’re going,’ he shouted. ‘Where are you going?’ ‘Sorry, Grandpa. I’m going kayaking.’ My wetsuit should have made it clear. Grandpa is Grandpa, and I try to ignore it when he gets angry. ‘Why train? You didn’t win the competition,’ he said. His words hurt, but I took a deep breath. He went to the bathroom and slammed the door. Mom came with a smile. ‘Don’t mind him. He’s…’ ‘…not himself right now,’ I said. I didn’t say he’s always like that. But, like Mom, I try to be patient. When I was a child, he was my hero. He showed me photos of him in National Geographic. Those photos are still on his wall, above his medals and trophies. But I don’t go into his room anymore. I have my own trophies now, and maybe one day, my face in National Geographic. Still, a part of me wants to stay close to him. Mom smiled. ‘At least he’s coming out of his room more. Have a good session, Rex. I admire your determination, even on cold days!’ I smiled back and peeled my banana. ‘It’ll be warmer in South America,’ I said. ‘If I find sponsors for my trip.’ She laughed and went back to the kitchen. I ate my banana and went downstairs. I went to the backyard and hurried to the boathouse.'

Text: Mum took Jess by the arm. "Come with me," she said. Jess followed her to the study. On the table, there was a painting. It was one of Grandpa's, but it looked different and was not finished. "Do you know anything about this?" Mum asked. Jess shook her head. "I've never seen it before. I didn't know he was working on anything." Jess looked at the picture. There was a river in it, but she didn't know the river. Maybe it was not a real river, just a fantasy one. The picture was strange and beautiful. There were no animals, birds, or people. It felt right that way. Jess thought about autumn coming after summer. Mum spoke again. "It has a name." Her voice sounded too casual, like she was hiding her excitement. Jess knew why. Grandpa never named his pictures. He just painted them and let others understand them. Mum turned the picture over and showed Jess the words Grandpa wrote. Jess read them aloud. "River Boy." The words seemed important to her, but she didn't know why. There was another mystery. She looked at Mum. "There is no boy." "Exactly. Strange, isn’t it? Maybe he will add the boy later. I asked him about it." "Mum! You should have known better." "I know, but I couldn't help it. It's such an unusual picture, especially with a name. You can guess what he said." Jess knew what Grandpa would say. "He said it's not the artist's job to explain a painting. Each picture has its own life and language, like a poem. We understand it or we don't. And he said painting is hard enough without explaining it to everyone." "Ignoramus, he said." "Yes, every ignoramus. If artists had to explain their pictures to everyone, they’d never finish their work. And he said …" Mum laughed and interrupted. "Something like that. I hoped you might know something about this painting because you seem to inspire him." "Inspire?" "Someone who gives an artist ideas." Jess knew the word. Grandpa often used it when she watched him paint. He would say the muse wasn't kind to him or he needed to be nice to the muse. She thought he meant a goddess, not a person. It was hard to think anyone could influence Grandpa. "He doesn't need me to inspire him," she said. "He's been painting all his life."

Text: 'This morning, I did not plan to cut a hole in my bedroom carpet. I am not saying it was an accident, but it could have been. For example, if I tripped over the bed with Dad’s knife in my hand, the knife might have cut the carpet. I am not saying this happened, just that it could have. I did not wake up thinking, ‘Today I will cut a hole in my carpet.’ It just seemed like a good idea at the time. Later, I wondered why I thought that, but it was too late. This happens to me a lot. I am unlucky that way. I was trying to fit my corner cabinet into a corner. Gran gave me the cabinet when she moved to a flat. It is small, white, with pink and blue flowers, and has tiny glass doors. Gran kept china ornaments in it. I keep shells, fossils, and stones there. I always loved Gran’s cabinet. I was excited when she gave it to me! But it is a corner cabinet, shaped like a triangle. It must stand in a corner. I have only two corners in my bedroom. My room is the smallest in the house, under the roof, and shaped like a wedge of cheese. Mum and Dad have the big front bedroom; my sister Angela has the back one; my brother Tom has the one over the garage; and I have the smallest one. Mum says when Angela goes to University, Tom can have her room, and I can have his. But Angela is only fifteen, so I will be in my small room for years. I do not mind; I like my little room. It is cosy, like a nest. I love the sloping roof and the window at floor level. The only problem is the lack of corners! My bed is in one, and my wardrobe in the other. I tried to fit Gran’s cabinet between the roof and the floor, but it was a little too tall. If I could cut a few centimetres off the bottom... Then I had an idea. If I could not cut the cabinet, maybe I could cut a hole in the carpet. It seemed like the obvious solution. Dad calls this lateral thinking. He always tells us to ‘think outside the box’. That is what I was doing!'

Text: 'The novel ‘The Borrowers’ is about a family of very small people who live hidden in the walls and floors of a house. They secretly take things from the normal-sized people to survive. When I was asked to direct a TV show of the novel, I knew it would be hard to meet people’s expectations. Fans of the book have strong ideas about how everything should look. I used the original drawings from the book because I didn't want people to say I got it wrong. The author wanted the series to show the Borrowers' view, not a human one, which made filming more difficult. The most important thing was getting the size right. The Borrowers are ten times smaller than humans, so if we filmed the Borrowers walking across a room or going on a borrowing mission, we had to be 10 times further away than usual. When filming the human surroundings, the crew had to crawl on the ground and film from no higher than 15 centimetres to get the Borrowers' view. They wore out many pairs of jeans! We never raised the cameras above their height except for aerial shots. One big challenge was getting the shadows right when the tiny Borrowers were combined with normal-sized backgrounds. We created a special technique for this. After the series was shown, the famous US film director George Lucas called and asked how I did it. The only permanent set we built was the Borrowers' home under the floorboards, filled with giant objects to make the actors look small. It was wonderfully strange. When I asked them to carry things like a giant pair of scissors, they really got into it. I remember the coins - they were bigger than dinner plates and hard to lift. We often had to stop filming because they made the crew laugh. But in the story, there’s a scene where the Borrowers are swept down a drain. To film this, actors had to be swept down a tunnel with hoses and said it was so scary, they didn’t have to act. One important thing for me was getting the costumes right. I had them made from heavy canvas so they stuck out like dolls’ clothes. This made it hard for the lead actress to bend in her costume. She couldn’t sit during breaks and couldn’t take the dress off because it was sewn on every morning. The lead actor’s trousers were made from a rug because normal material would look too smooth. Unfortunately, the weather was very hot during filming. I don’t think they thanked me for the costumes! Most of the action away from the Borrowers’ home was filmed with the actors separated from their surroundings. We filmed them in front of a blue screen on an empty set. It was hard for them to react to things that weren't there. I had to draw pictures of every scene to show how each one should look – I did 2,000 of them by the end. They weren’t very accurate, but they worked well enough. The budget didn’t allow time in special effects studios during the day, so I worked nights for three months. We had to work hard and fast – I once shot a whole scene before realising there was no film in the camera. But it all came together in the end, and I think the series was successful in showing the magic of the books.'

Text: Mom stops the car at the corner of my new school, Palm Grove High School. She looks around nervously for journalists, but there are none. I wonder how long it will be before the craziness starts. It always does. The fake smiles, the people who want to be friends, the ones who ask for free tickets to my dad’s concerts. "Everything’s going to be fine," I tell her. She kisses her fingertip and touches my cheek before I get out of the car. Then she drives away, leaving me alone with this new school and new situation. But this is what I wanted. I wanted to leave my old life on the road and with tutors. While the band is here for recording, we are staying for good. I wanted to come to this school to meet real kids. Maybe a kid with a mom who works in an office or a dad who cuts grass. That would be so normal. I walk into the school’s main office. "Hi, I need my schedule, please," I tell the school secretary. "Name?" she asks, not very friendly. "Desert McGraw." "Desirée?" she asks, leaning closer. "Desert," I repeat. She seems confused. "Oh," she says and types "McGraw" on her keyboard. That’s good. Few people know my last name because my dad uses his stage name. "What grade?" "Eleventh." "One second, it’s printing," she says. Then she gives me the paper. English Literature, first period. Cool, I like English. I’ll be late, though. English is in Room 214, second floor. I studied the map last night, so I don’t look lost. When I get to the door, the teacher is already calling names. "Aurelio Gonzalez." "Here." I slip in quietly and sit in the last desk in the second row. The girl next to me smiles. She looks at my outfit – jeans and a T-shirt. Ha! Nobody will suspect me now! "Nice shoes," she whispers. I look at my expensive shoes with flowers. Oh no, I shouldn’t have worn these. "Thanks," I say. The teacher pauses. "Desert... McGraw?" she says. "Here." The teacher smiles and says her name is Ms. Smigla. She talks a lot and gives us our course outlines. After we review them, she lets us talk! All teachers should do this. "So why’d you move here?" my new friend asks. I have many choices. Do I say I wanted a normal life away from cameras and reporters? Or the real reason, according to Dad? "We need a change, Desert," he said, "and this is the perfect place to record the new album. Energy, color, culture... just what our last album needed." Personally, I think he just wants to relax on the beach. Why else pick a studio near the sand? "My dad had to relocate," I tell her. Yes, lies work better. "What does he do?" she asks. Oh well, everyone will find out soon. But I’ll have some time to be normal until then. "He’s an artist," I say, playing with my backpack zipper. "Cool. I’m Becca, by the way." And she doesn’t care. Excellent.

Text: 'Today, American teenage girls are expected to do many things. They should be Student Council president, have a part-time job, volunteer, and do well in everything. This is what it means to be a teenager in America now. Teenage boys and girls cannot just go to school and be average. Being average is not enough. People think that if you do not try hard, you are lazy. Teenagers have a lot of pressure. They have homework, tests, activities after school, jobs, chores at home, and they also try to have a social life. Kristen Loose, a teenager, says that people forget how much pressure teenagers have. Even with all this stress, people still think teenagers are lazy, disrespectful, and only care about themselves. Kristen says this is not true. She uses her phone a lot, but not just for fun. It helps her with her life and school. Teenagers today need to be connected all the time. They use smartphones and tablets to do homework anywhere. Schoolwork and activities need attention all the time, not just at school. Many teenagers start their day at 6 a.m. or 7 a.m. and finish after midnight. They have school, activities, family duties, and homework. They do this every day with less than nine hours of sleep. The US National Sleep Foundation found that only 20% of teens get nine hours of sleep. Also, 28% of teens fall asleep in school once a week because they are tired. Lindamarie Olsen, another teenager, says she has about 18 hours of free time a week. This is not much out of 168 hours in a week. She does not waste this time on social media or TV. She likes to volunteer. Olsen says people think teenagers only care about themselves, but she loves helping others. Her favorite time of the week is when she volunteers. In the future, teenagers will still prove people wrong and make the world better. There will be new students who will change the world before they finish school.'

Text: 'The teenage members of the Earth to Sky Calculus Club live in Bishop, a small town in the US near the Sierra Nevada mountains. Over the last few years, this group has sent more than fifty balloons to the edge of space, about 35 km above the Earth. This is a science project that is also an adventure, which is why teenagers like it. I join them one weekend in late spring. They are about to release a high-altitude balloon to record shooting stars. Shooting stars happen when a rock or metal from space enters the Earth's atmosphere, making a light trail. As it gets dark, the teenagers attach a soft $5 lunch box to the balloon. Inside is a camera, a tool to measure height, and a thermometer. Two GPS trackers are on the outside to help find it later. A gas tank, given by a fan from a nearby state, is used to fill the balloon, which grows to the size of a small car. An older boy drove seven hours to get it. ‘I didn’t really mind,’ he says. For kids in this club, that’s normal. Finally, it's time to let the balloon go. ‘Five, four, three, two, one,’ they say, and the balloon goes up. Some of them run and follow it with flashlights until they can't see it anymore. There is quiet and a feeling of wonder. Then the balloon disappears into the night. After the launch, most students go home, but a few stay to watch the shooting stars. They lie on blankets and look at the clear sky. It’s hard to believe they are just four hours from Los Angeles, a big city with about 4 million people. I see a boy get into a sleeping bag and fall asleep. ‘We’re the only ones talking,’ says one girl quietly. ‘I know,’ whispers another. A meteor crosses the sky. As the balloon rises, the air pressure drops and the balloon gets bigger until it pops. A parachute helps the lunch box land safely. The students will find it the next day using the GPS trackers. Getting it back is not easy, but that’s part of the fun. There is not much land with people around Bishop, so the lunch box usually lands in the middle of nowhere. ‘To me, finding the lunch box is a big part of the program,’ says the group’s leader. They have lost only two lunch boxes in 53 launches. ‘We learn about the land in a way you never would.’ This time, the lunch box landed 84 km west of Bishop. To get it, the team had to drive south of the Sierra and then up the other side. They had to decide if driving or walking was better. It could be dangerous if the lunch box was on a high peak or a tall tree. ‘These students are from the Eastern Sierra,’ their leader says. ‘What seems wild to some is normal to them.’ It took them 11 hours to find the lunch box. It was in a canyon, on a flat rock, in a waterfall. The camera didn’t record any shooting stars. It’s a bit disappointing, but it’s a chance to talk about atmospheric waves and how they work over mountains. And it’s another adventure story to share.'

Text: 'Chloe Morgan says she didn't like science, especially Palaeontology, until she was fifteen. It happened by accident. Her younger brother loved dinosaurs, which is common for kids, but Chloe didn't. She helped him with a science project and found an article about new discoveries. It amazed her, and she knew she wanted to study Palaeontology. I asked her if anyone encouraged her because Palaeontology was not a common job for young people then. She remembers meeting her first professional palaeontologist, Matt Cornelius. He was famous and young. Chloe was nervous to meet him, even though he was friendly. She worried he would think she was just a kid asking too many questions. But he was patient and listened to her. I asked Chloe about palaeontologists in movies and TV shows. She thinks movies like Jurassic Park make people interested in dinosaurs but not always in Palaeontology. She says movies show palaeontologists as strange geniuses or nerds who can't talk to people. They don't show what palaeontologists really do every day. Chloe's job is different every day. She digs up dinosaur bones, works in labs, studies fossils, and writes for science magazines. She also talks to the public about science when she can. She thinks it's important to explain science to people, especially young people. Talking about dinosaurs can make kids excited about science and help them learn more. Chloe helped with a TV show called Walking with Dinosaurs. She says the show makers knew a lot, and she only gave advice if needed. She checked that the dinosaurs shown lived at the same time. The show was popular with all ages because it showed dinosaurs in a new way. Chloe thinks dinosaurs are interesting because they make us want to explore and discover new things. They remind us there is still more to learn about the world. Palaeontology is like time travel.'

Text: "I will say this once: when you travel by car with your family, even if you are six years old, you know you are not 'there yet,' even if you keep asking 'Are we there yet?' When you arrive, it is not 'there' anymore; it is 'here.' So, if you think you are 'there,' you should ask 'Are we here yet?' Parents want to be 'there' more than kids do because they hear this question many times during long car trips. Kids should not complain. They can relax in the back seat, watch DVDs, listen to music, or do puzzles while the scenery passes by outside. In the front seat, mum or dad gives out juice boxes and cookies, changes the radio, and keeps everything running smoothly. Are we there yet? I hope not. But sometimes, someone in the car does something annoying, like my younger brother, Tim. He might put his foot on my side of the seat. I put my foot on his side, and soon we are fighting. Mum or dad separates us and tells Tim to stay in his seat. This calms things down for a while. The scenery continues to pass by. Later, I try to read, but I feel a breeze on my arm. Tim is blowing on me from his seat. He is not touching me, so he thinks he is not doing anything wrong. I get angry, and Tim gets in trouble again. Then things calm down. Dad has ways to deal with us in the back seat. When we ask 'Are we there yet?' he sometimes says, 'Yes, we are here. Get out of the car.' We say, 'But Dad, we are still on the highway.' He replies, 'Oh, maybe we are not there yet.' This makes us quiet for a while. You know you are 'there' when the adults get out of the car and move away from the kids. So remember: if mum and dad can still answer your question, then the answer is: no, you are not there yet."

John and Zuzi Morgan have opened a café in Oxford, UK. In their café, people can drink coffee, eat cake, and play board games. John and Zuzi hope people will enjoy this and come back again. Zuzi says they started the café because people are always on their phones and gadgets. They want people to talk and have fun together without screens.

The games in their café are called 'Eurogames'. These games have simple themes like farming. The first Eurogame was The Settlers of Catan, made by Klaus Teuber from Germany. In this game, players build settlements and trade resources. Everyone stays involved until the end, and no one feels left out. Later, 'co-operative' games were made where everyone wins or loses together. This makes people talk and work together more. One popular co-operative game is Pandemic, made by Matt Leacock from North America. In Pandemic, players solve global problems together. Leacock was inspired by a game called Lord of the Rings.

Leacock loved board games since he was a child, even though he sometimes found them disappointing. With his uncle, he tried to make better games. Pandemic became very popular. The new version of Pandemic has a lot of storytelling. It is like a video game because you can develop characters and change the game world.

Video games have helped board games become popular. Many people play games on their phones now. Ben Hogg, who works for a games company, says more people are open to playing games. Before, people played video games together in the same room. Now, many video games are played online, and players are not in the same place. Some people miss playing games with others in person. John and Zuzi's café shows that board games are more than just fun. In our online world, people like to share games in real life, and this trend will continue.

Text: 'Jamie Scott has written and produced some of the biggest UK songs in recent years. His story shows why hard work and not giving up are important in the music business, even if your career starts slowly. His mother was a great singer and taught him to play the guitar. At home, he only listened to a local radio station for older people, which influenced him as he grew up. He was 12 when he first heard a modern song. Around that time, he had to choose between playing tennis, which he did at a national level, and music. He spent his school lunchtimes playing the piano. He says, ‘I was good at tennis, but I didn’t want to do it forever. It was too much work.’ At 17, he left school to become a performer. He was in a duo with a friend who was a good guitarist but not as interested in a music career. Jamie told his parents he wanted to write songs and play music. His dad gave him 18 months to succeed, or he would have to find a job. After some close calls with record labels, he signed with a music publisher at 19 because of one song. But record labels wanted him to be a solo artist, so he left the duo. He became famous working behind the scenes, not on stage. After a tough time with a UK record label, he moved to another label to release a new album, but he didn’t become famous. He says, ‘In my own artist career, I was often in the wrong place at the wrong time. But as a writer, I was in the right place at the right time.’ Writing for others is where he succeeded. He says, ‘I think I am one of the main writers in the UK that labels send new artists to.’ He helps start their careers. Sometimes he tells artists that writing songs for the charts is okay. ‘Why not? Don’t you want 10 million people to listen to your music next month? We should write something amazing that will also sell well.’ It is nice to hear someone talk honestly about wanting to write big hit songs. Jamie is not arrogant; he just knows he wants to write number one songs and is good at it. He focuses on writing the best music. ‘When I go into the studio, we need to aim for global success and write the best music of next year. It’s not just about being cool. We want to write classic modern pop songs.’'

Tony Connor is a new kind of famous person. He is very popular online, but people who do not watch online videos might not know him. Tony is a 'street trials cyclist'. He jumps from one place to another, like from a roof to a wall, on his bike. These jumps are filmed and put online. 

I met Tony in a BMX park on a Saturday morning. Many local boys and older people knew him and called him 'an absolute legend'. After watching him, I agreed. I was surprised by his bravery and imagination. Before each jump, Tony explained what he wanted to do. I did not always believe he could do it, but he did. When I praised him, he did not seem very happy. Even though he is famous online, Tony does not like being a celebrity. He finds it hard to talk to fans and prefers doing things instead of talking about them.

Tony's fame comes from social media and new camera technology. This technology helps him make a living. He says many people are always looking at screens, and he does not always like that. But he is not complaining. His videos help him earn money from what used to be just a hobby.

I have learned that to become a top athlete, you need energy and the ability to handle disappointment. These are more important than talent. In risky sports, you need mental strength. Even in the park, Tony fell a few times but kept trying until he succeeded.

Not everyone thinks Tony is a hero. Some say he takes too many risks. Tony says these people do not understand his sport. They do not know he gets advice from experts to stay safe. Tony is careful about risks. He says some people never get scared, but he does. He finds a way to overcome fear. He is not addicted to risk and spends a lot of time planning. Before a new jump, he prepares his mind. He knows he must be confident before he jumps. If he is fully committed, he is okay.

Text: 'Television presenter Helen Skelton has done many dangerous things for charity. She ran a marathon in the desert and traveled down the Amazon river in a small boat. For her latest challenge, Helen walked on a high wire. This is a long, thin piece of metal, 66 meters above the ground, between two towers of an empty power station. There was no safety net, only a belt around her waist attached to another wire above. To help her balance and not fall, she carried a long stick that weighed eight kilograms. Helen learned from an expert high-wire walker. Even though she knew some circus skills, she found high-wire walking very different. ‘The training was a surprise’, said Helen. ‘I didn’t know how strong I needed to be. Every day started at 8 am with a run up a steep hill; then an hour of exercises, with another hour after my day on the wire. I also had to learn how to fall on the wire so I could continue if I slipped. Every time I fell, it hurt a lot. But it was important to stay positive: if I was nervous and started shaking, the wire would shake too!’ On the day of the challenge, it was windy. Helen stayed calm by taking deep breaths as she moved step by step along the wire. The 150-meter walk took 15 minutes. ‘That was the scariest thing I’ve done,’ she said afterwards. ‘I’m glad it’s over!’ But Helen is still planning her next charity project: to reach the South Pole by ski, kite, and bike.'

Text: 'In 2006, Jeff Somers started a trip around the world on a penny farthing. A penny farthing is an old bicycle with one big wheel and one small wheel. Jeff had already written a book about traveling around Canada in a 50-year-old car. He loved motor sports and worked building racing car engines. To save money, Jeff rode an old bicycle to work and even used it to go to Amsterdam for a holiday. ‘That trip opened my eyes,’ he says. ‘I decided to see the world by bike.’ Jeff didn’t want a normal bike and wanted to build one himself. ‘The craziest bicycle I could think of was a penny farthing, so I went to the museum to see how they were made.’ After two failed attempts in 2001 and 2003 because of a knee injury, he finally started his journey in 2006. He traveled for three years through 23 countries on four continents. The best part of the trip was arriving in Tibet and seeing Mount Everest. ‘I met cyclists who could ride up mountains, which I couldn’t do, but I never regretted my penny farthing. The further from home I got, the more amazed people were by it.’ His worst moment was when he had to drink dirty water from a stream. He got very sick and stayed in bed for ten days without medicine. He had no money for hospital bills or to go home. Despite all this, Jeff now says, ‘if I could afford it, I would travel again tomorrow on my penny farthing.’'

Text: 'I work at a university in the US. My team and I are learning about water birds, especially the American black duck. We have started using a new tool called a 'night-vision scope'. This tool helps us see the ducks in the dark! We are worried about black ducks because their numbers have gone down a lot. We don't know if there is enough food for them on the east coast. We know a lot about what they do during the day, but not at night. We didn't have the right tools before. But now, this new scope gives us clear pictures, even on nights without the moon. We can learn more and make better plans to help them. The work is hard. There are four of us, and each person works six hours a day. We study ducks in different places. I sometimes take a boat to see the ducks and write notes about them. The weather is not always good. Some nights are nice, but often it is wet. It is so quiet that I need a lot of coffee to stay awake! We only missed one day of work because the snow was too deep, even for our snow vehicles. I like the challenge, especially when I think about summer. In summer, we will work in a lab to look at our results. It will be hard to stay inside, but it is important. I wouldn't change my job for anything!'

Text: 'When I tell people about my job, they can hardly believe it. But I’m not joking! I work by eating chocolate! Tasting chocolate is important to make sure customers get perfect chocolate bars from my company. Every week, I get small samples from our factory. I check them for taste, texture, and smell. I also taste the raw materials we use, like nuts and fruit. I spend time choosing the best ones for the chocolate. Next to my office, I have a kitchen where I test and taste products. I give samples to my colleagues, and they are happy! My kitchen has many machines and ingredients. It’s nice to have a private space to go to during the day. Every day is different in this job. Sometimes I am at our food lab, and other times I travel to buy raw materials. I have a young family, so traveling can be hard. But I love the variety and the lack of routine in my job. The question people ask me most is if I get bored of chocolate. I have worked with it for a long time, and I still love to eat it. I even eat more chocolate at home in the evening!'

Text: 'Have you ever thought about what it’s like to perform in a circus? Sophia Grayson is from Circus Experience - a place where young people learn circus skills. She says her course is popular because it teaches many skills, like juggling, throwing and catching things like balls or even fire, and trapeze, which means flying through the air above an amazed audience. In the year-long course, students slowly take more risks in each class, and parents come to some classes to see how they are doing. Sophia explains, “For a circus career, performers need to do different things – it’s important to keep performances exciting. If you want to be successful in the circus, you must keep practising. Another great thing is making friends with other performers and learning from them. Being fit is also very important - circus artists, like athletes, train every day to stay strong. Training is very important, but the best performers are those who want success, have imagination, and never stop improving their skills. People often think you might get hurt, or that you might only work for a short time each year. But, actually, the real issue is planning for the future because you can only travel while you’re young and then you need to think about other options.” The course also teaches business planning. Many past students start businesses all over the world and are happy to share their experiences. Sophia warns, however, it’s not a job for making money! “The work usually means not having a regular salary. It’s also competitive - but great fun!”'

Text: 'You may not know her name or her face, but you’ve probably heard her many times. Mariam Hobson is a professional backing singer. She helps the main singer by singing in the background. Some people think backing singers aren’t good enough to be lead singers. That’s not true – they have to be very good. People like Mariam are important in the music industry! ‘What I love about my job is that when I go to the recording studio, I never know what I’ll sing,’ she says. ‘It could be classical, jazz, hip-hop, or rock. Or it might be a funny little song for a radio station or an advertisement. I’m often surprised by what producers ask. I was once asked to sing like a fish underwater! But I never argue, I just do the job!’ ‘Excellent musical skills are important for my work, plus the ability to learn quickly. There’s often no written music to look at. I’ll never forget my first time recording background music for a film. It was very hard because there were eight of us, each singing a different tune, and an orchestra too. I was scared: I knew that if I made a mistake, we would have to record everything again, which nobody likes. Recording sessions are long enough already.’ ‘One of my favorite jobs is recording for songwriters. Less experienced writers don’t always know which musical range is best for the female voice. By listening to me sing their song, they can find out how to make it better.’'

Text: 'Julie Deane started with only a little fashion knowledge, but she made a successful business with her 'satchels' - a traditional bag used by schoolchildren. These satchels are now sold in famous shops and are popular with many celebrities. Before choosing satchels, Julie thought about different businesses, like cake decorating and party planning. She did not choose her first idea. When she decided on satchels, not everyone agreed with her. Julie says, 'Many said there was no demand for them – but I was convinced.' She worked with her family from the start, especially her mother, who had never had a career but was good at business. The design came from children's storybooks. Julie did not know much about fashion blogs, but they helped her success. At first, she sold about one satchel a week. To get interest, Julie sent satchels to fashion writers and hoped they would write about them in their blogs. They did, and interest grew, as did the speed her company made the satchels. Julie now loves seeing which celebrity has a satchel! While other companies spend money on online ads, she uses the internet community for new style ideas, keeping her products fresh. There was a hard time when another company copied Julie's design to sell similar bags. Now, she makes sure she trusts her production team as much as her own staff. Visitors say the offices have a positive feeling – people love working there. There is now a new factory, and while buildings are important, it is the team that makes it special.'

Text: 'When Vicky Harmiston was a child, her parents let her and her brother Jamie choose what to do in their free time. Vicky chose to do many sports. She was a good swimmer, and the coach at her swimming club thought she could become a champion. But the club was far from her home, so it was hard for her to train and do her schoolwork. When they were teenagers, Jamie, who loved cycling, bought a special racing bike and started joining competitions. Vicky thought it looked very exciting and decided to try it too. She says it was the best decision she ever made. Soon she was cycling every day and doing very well. The track was near her school, so she could easily go to training after school every day. Vicky had a successful career in track cycling and won several competitions. Then, when she was 28, she stopped competing. Vicky said: ‘For years I loved winning competitions, but I got a bit tired of it – and when the excitement stops, there’s no point. Luckily, I started a new career.’ Vicky got a job with a charity called CycleZone. ‘We work with young people who have never enjoyed sport,’ she says. ‘The first thing we do is teach them to ride a bike. We want them to believe in themselves and their abilities. CycleZone does a great job, and it brings young people together so they’re part of a bigger group.’ The charity uses famous people to advertise their work. Vicky says, ‘I know some people aren’t sure if having a celebrity is always good for a charity. They say the celebrities only do it to make themselves look good, which stops people from seeing the real work of the charity. But if famous singers and actors can help, I think they should.’'

Text: 'Ana Ronson is a singer and songwriter from Ireland. Her parents were not musicians, but there was always music at home. Her grandfather played the guitar and taught Ana and her brother. The first time Ana sang in front of people was at school. She was so nervous that her teacher had to help her off the stage. The teacher suggested she join the school theatre club to become more confident. After some time in the club, she sang with 50 other students at a concert. A year later, her brother, who was in a band, asked her to write a song for them. She wrote her first song, Falling Stars, in just three days. She liked it so much that she joined a songwriting course. Even though she was the youngest, she knew more about music than many others. But Ana says the teacher didn’t listen to her, so she wrote a song called Something to Say about how this made her feel. She put the song online, and it became very popular. People left comments saying they loved it and found new meanings in the words. Joss Alton, who owns a recording company called Isotope Music, came from the other side of Ireland to ask her to join Isotope. At first, she wasn’t sure because she didn’t know the company and didn’t want someone to tell her what to sing. But Joss convinced her, and soon she performed at a concert in Dublin organized by Isotope. They sold all the tickets quickly, and it was a great evening. Ana says she likes writing songs about difficult times because there is more to say. One of her favorite songs is Decision, about why her brother stopped singing for a while and how it made him unhappy. She hopes fans like her songs, but her goal is to write about personal experiences that are important to her.'

Text: 'Last year, I went on a great trip. I traveled by boat with a group along the west coast of Canada. It was my brother Harry’s idea. He is a journalist, like me, and he wanted to write about the trip. He loves boats, but I do not. I wanted to visit the area because I saw it on TV when I was a child. Our great-grandparents lived there before moving to Europe. I asked Harry if I could go too, and he said yes! A few days before we left, there were storms where we were going. But the weather was good when we were there. I was busy at work, so I did not have much time to plan. But Harry said he took care of everything, so I stopped worrying. After we arrived in Canada, we joined the group. We packed our things into small boats and left. The guide said not many people live along that coast. On the first morning, we only saw dolphins and birds. There were islands far away, but it was foggy, so we could not see them well. I watched the patterns our boat made in the water. We often stopped to explore rock pools on the beaches. They had many colorful fish. I did not know many of them. It was nice not to worry about time. We always made lunch and dinner together over campfires. At night, we slept on the boats. The beds were hard, but it was relaxing! When it was time to leave, I was sad. How could I go back to normal life? But I knew I would miss my family and friends. I also wanted to tell everyone at home about our adventures!'

Text: 'My dad was a professional basketball player in Germany, just like his father. When I was a child, I went to watch many of his games. You might think I would love basketball because of this, but I didn't. I liked telling my friends how good my dad was, especially when he won, but I often took a book to read instead of watching the games. When I started secondary school, I was not yet a teenager but was already two metres tall. My sports teacher saw my height and asked if I wanted to train with the basketball team. I enjoyed the training, but I thought I needed to improve before playing a real game. The teacher believed in me more than I did. After a few weeks, I played against another school. My mum and dad came to watch, which made me nervous, but it was OK in the end! For the next four years, I practised every day and did well. I even joined an adult team before moving to a special sports academy in the USA when I was fifteen. The coach there trains Olympic players, and it was great to work with him. However, I didn't enjoy living far from my parents at first. At home, I didn't spend much time with friends because of training, so that part didn't change much. I got used to my new life, and my English got better quickly! I became a professional player at eighteen, three years after moving to the USA. I was taller than most players since I was fifteen, but I was too light for my height, so I had to fix that first. My coach knew a team that would take me while I was still in college, so I joined them and have never regretted it.'

Text: 'Seven years ago, I was studying Tourism at college. I needed a part-time job because my course was expensive. I thought about different jobs and decided to become a weekend tour guide in my city, Chicago, USA. I took visitors around the city and was surprised to find out how much I liked it. I saw my city in a new way, like the tourists did. After I finished my studies, I wanted to be a full-time tour guide. I thought it would be easy, but I learned I needed a lot more knowledge to get a licence. Chicago guides must answer many questions about the city, like its buildings, history, and public transport. After some hard but interesting months, I got my tour guide qualification and became an independent tour guide. Tour guiding is not just about knowing facts or keeping the group together. You need other skills too. You should be entertaining and tell interesting stories. You also need to handle changes, like if a place is closed or a route changes. Tourists want to enjoy a well-organised tour. I must make sure visitors are happy, or they might write a bad review online. Good reviews bring more customers. That’s why making tours fun and stress-free is important. I put a lot of energy into my job, so my reviews are usually very good, and people often recommend my tours to other visitors in Chicago.'

My name is Ella and I am 22 years old. Last year, I went to Thailand for two weeks with my sister Josie. Josie is five years younger than me, but we get along well. We went to help as volunteers at an elephant sanctuary. This is a place where people take care of sick and rescued elephants. At first, I was not sure if we would have much in common with the other volunteers because they were older than us. We were also nervous because it was our first time doing something like this. But in the end, we did not need to worry. 

One of our main jobs at the sanctuary was to collect food for the elephants. Elephants eat a lot of grass and banana plants, so this took most of the day. Josie found it hard work, but I thought it was worth it to see the elephants enjoy their food. We also helped wash the elephants in the river with big brushes and soap. I had a lot of fun doing this, even if I got wetter than the elephants!

In the evening, we took the elephants into the forest where they stayed at night. All the volunteers lived in the same house. Josie and I shared a bedroom, so it was small. We chose to share because Josie did not want to be alone. It was hot and humid, especially at night, but we knew it would be like that. The meals were delicious and did not have meat, which we liked. After dinner, we talked and played games with the other volunteers and staff.

Now that we are back in the UK, Josie does not talk much about Thailand. But if someone asks her if she liked the sanctuary, she says she loved it. I am not sure she is telling the truth. I think she might be a bit upset because she missed her friends too much and did not enjoy her time there fully. But when she thinks about it, she knows she was lucky to go. Maybe she will go back one day – I know I will!

Text: 'I’m Gina D’Costa and I have a flower shop in the UK. We sell flowers to many people. Some people buy flowers for friends or for their homes. Hotels and offices also want flowers for their Reception. Sometimes, we give flowers for business photos. Once, I decorated a castle with flowers for a wedding. It was a lot of work, but I was very happy with it. My day starts at 4 a.m. I go to the market to buy fresh flowers. Most people are still sleeping then. My friends think I am crazy, but I love my work. It is often cold and dark, but I don’t mind. The flower market is wonderful. There are flowers from all over the world. It is hard to choose because there are so many. I like pink flowers the most, but I must remember that other people like different flowers. Not all flowers are available all year. I don’t like arguing about prices with the sellers, but it is part of the job. Flowers are not cheap, so I try to get the best price. Back at the shop, we look at customer orders and put flowers in vases. Then we make flower bunches and decide how much they cost. Customers are often surprised by the price, and I sometimes ask them to choose again. Some people think this is too much work, but I like making nice flower bunches for the money people want to spend. I love my job and wouldn’t want any other!'

Text: 'My city has a modern cinema that shows all the new films I want to see, and many films for kids on the weekends. It is very close to where I live. But a year ago, I felt something was missing – talking about a film with people after watching it. So, I started a film club with two friends! We decided not to rent a cinema to show the films. Instead, we choose a different place in the city each month. For example, we used an old factory to show a film set in Antarctica. It was very cold, and this made the film feel real, which was great! Some places we use are free because the owners sell snacks during the film, so we can keep our prices low. We just want to cover our costs, not make money. Each time we show a film, it gets easier, especially now that we have our own equipment. We also know how many tickets we sell because everything is online – no more worries about empty seats! There is still a lot to do, but when people of all ages say they had a great time, it feels wonderful. The website helps us a lot, and we now talk to other film clubs in the country. We have visited them to see how they do things, but it is always nice to come back to our own club! We started a blog because most people look online for film information now, not in local newspapers. We also put up some posters in cafés. But nothing works as well as people telling their friends about us. The audience loves the special activities we do with each film – last month we had a movie quiz, and everyone enjoyed it.'

Text: 'When I was a child, I loved taking photos. At 15, I wanted to make my hobby more serious. So, I started a project: I would take one photo every day for a year. Many young photographers had done this before, but I thought it was a great idea. After a few weeks, I put my photos on a website for young photographers. I wanted to make a photo diary and show my photos to others. I was happy to see that people liked my photos. I enjoyed taking photos of many things. Then, someone said my project would be better if all my photos had a common theme. I agreed and started taking photos of nature, like birds and the sky. Many of my photos were black and white, which was different because other young photographers took color photos. Sometimes, I doubted my project and almost stopped. But I trusted myself and became more confident. One day, I showed my project to my art teacher. She told me about a national photography competition for people my age. I entered my photos for fun. I will never forget when the judges said I won first prize. I was so happy because my project was important to me. It was the first time I thought my photography was good, and maybe I could be a professional photographer. Now, I have my own photography studio and I am happy with my career choice.'

Text: 'I joined the National Youth Challenge (NYC) last year because I wanted to try camping, sailing, and learn skills like public speaking. These were new things for me. In the NYC, you can do different activities to challenge yourself and learn new things. There are different levels, from beginner to advanced, and adult volunteers called ‘leaders’ help you. When you finish each level, you get a certificate. 

When I first joined, my leader suggested I help organise activities at a local children’s club for two hours a week. I wasn’t sure it was a good idea because I had joined that club when I was eight and found it hard to make friends. I was shy, and the other children already had their own friends, so I stopped going after a few weeks. I decided to try the challenge because I wanted my first NYC certificate. Soon, I wanted to spend all my free time at the children’s club. It became more important to me than just getting the certificate. When I finished the challenge, the NYC leader let me keep volunteering at the club because I made good relationships with the children. Now I go there for about four hours a week and I really look forward to it.

Because of what I learned at the children’s club, I decided that when I finish school in three years, I want to go to college to become a youth worker – someone who works with children. I never thought about this before starting at the club. I had never thought about my future job, and the idea of youth work was new to me. This has been my favourite part of the NYC so far, and I’ve improved my communication skills while helping others. I have several other NYC certificates now, and yes, one of them is for camping!'

Text: 'I was born in Denver, USA. I started snowboarding when I was eight years old. My dad took me to a mountain resort, two hours from Denver. The hill looked very steep, and my dad had to convince me to try snowboarding. I was young and had not thought about snowboarding, but my dad loved it and wanted me to love it too. He made it look easy. In the end, I did well. After this, I loved the sport and got better at it. I started competing when I was ten. Some people do many competitions and get bored, but I still love competing and winning. This helps me try harder. I like not having a fixed plan. Sometimes this works well, like when I got a perfect score of 100 at a local competition. I was not sure I would try the jumps that gave me this score until I started. This made me trust my abilities more. In the summer, I train and study because there is no snow. I train every day, but I do not have to follow a strict diet like in winter. I also spend time with my friends. This helps me when I cannot snowboard. I think about my future. Snowboarding is a big part of my life, but I want something else to do if I do not become a professional snowboarder or if I get hurt. I wonder if I can become a doctor if I have time for college. I cannot imagine getting tired of snowboarding, but I cannot snowboard my whole life.'

Text: 'When I was fifteen, I wanted everything my friends had. I never thought about the future. For example, I didn't know what I wanted to do after school. One day, my best friend got a new phone for her birthday. I wanted one too. My parents said I could have it if I paid for it myself. So, I decided to work part-time and save money. I learned a lot from this. I worked every Saturday in a café, but I didn't like it. My parents suggested I start my own small business. I saw my mum making necklaces, so I asked if I could try. I thought it was hard, but it was easier than I expected. My friends thought it was boring, but I liked it. Mum showed me how to make nice things at home with simple tools. I sold my first jewellery to friends and family. They said they liked them, but I thought they were just being nice. I wanted to know if other people would like them too. So, I rented a market stall with my mum. Many tourists come to my town, and they bought my jewellery as gifts. Soon, people from all over the country called to buy more. They thought we were a big company, but it was just me and my mum at a market stall! That was when I knew it could work, and I decided to make a website. Since then, I have made a lot of money with my business, mostly online, but we still have our stall too. It has been a lot of fun.'

Text: 'When Janine Stuart was only 13, she wrote a book called Being Amelia. This book became very popular. Being Amelia is a little bit about Janine’s life. In an interview, Janine said, ‘Because of my father’s job, my family moved around the country a lot, so I’ve become good at making new friends. I know what it’s like to be the new student in a class, and that helped me write about Amelia, the main character, who goes to a new school. Some funny parts of the book are about Amelia’s home life, especially with her older brother. I am my parents’ only child, so I used my imagination to write that.’ Janine started her book one summer when she was bored at home. Her mother always wanted to be a writer, and her teachers always told her to write, so it seemed like a good way for Janine to spend her time. The year before, she entered a short story competition on a young writers’ website and won first prize. That’s why, when Janine finished Being Amelia and sent it to a publishing company, they wanted to read it. They loved it, and a year later, Janine’s book was in bookshops. One review of Being Amelia says that even though the book has pictures of happy teenagers on the cover, the people in the story have some hard times, and this makes readers believe in them. The reviewer says that even though Janine is still very young, and Being Amelia isn’t a very long book, she is a better writer than some other popular authors. Janine is still getting used to being a famous writer: ‘At first, I hid when people knew me in the street, but now it’s OK. I’d like to give advice to other young writers, but they have to find what works for them. For me, I know that all I have to do is spend time with my friends, and I’ll soon have something interesting to write about!’'

Text: 'I’m Tom. I’m fifteen years old. Three years ago, my family and I moved to a castle on a small island. My father got a job as the castle’s manager. He works for a group that takes care of old buildings and lets people visit them. He was happy because he thought he wouldn’t get another chance like this. But it took some time for us to agree that Dad should take the job. We were thinking about what life on the island would be like. We knew the castle might not be as comfortable as our nice home across the water, and there was no school. After we moved, we got used to living on the island. The castle isn’t very beautiful, but our apartment is comfortable. In summer, the island is busy because many people visit, and there are often parties on the beach. In winter, we only see the other families who live here, and there aren’t many teenagers, which I hoped for. The adults help each other with repairs on the island, which is hard work. The biggest change for me was taking a boat every day to my old school. I was excited to go on stormy days with big waves, but the ferries don’t run then! If I miss the bus to the harbour after school, I miss the last ferry home, which is a problem. So when friends come home with me, I tell them to hurry up! But we often see amazing views, like when the sun sets over the sea. Some days, it’s so foggy you can’t see anything, then it’s sunny again in a few hours – it’s still amazing to me. We do have bad storms, and I sometimes worry if the castle is strong enough. But then I remember it’s been here for hundreds of years – and it’s still standing!'

Text: 'I live in a house in the beautiful countryside in Scotland. I love nature and wild animals. Six years ago, I started a new hobby – birdwatching! I went to some mountains in northern Scotland with my family. We saw many birds in their natural home. I spent hours watching them with my parents. They showed me how to tell the difference between bird types and where to find the best places to see them. It was amazing! After we came home, I joined a local young birdwatchers’ club. My goal is to see 200 different bird types. I am close to reaching my goal because on family holidays abroad, I have seen birds from other countries too. We always look for places with group birdwatching activities, so I can add new birds to my list! I’ve been to Egypt, and last summer we went to South America. I thought I’d see my 200th bird there. I wasn’t too sad when it didn’t happen, because I’ve learned you have to be patient with this hobby. I posted a video online about this challenge. Many teenagers liked it and said it looked like a fun hobby. When my teachers saw it, they asked me to give a presentation about birdwatching at school. I wasn’t nervous until just before I walked onto the stage. I knew I’d remember what to say and had some notes to help me, but the whole school and all my friends were watching me! I only relaxed when it was over. The teachers said I’d prepared well and they really enjoyed it. I might do another one next year! I’m lucky to live in the countryside. I understand why many teenagers in cities might not think of becoming birdwatchers, but there are many birds to see, especially in places with lots of green areas. I also think birdwatching clubs should try to get more young people interested in this hobby. Everyone needs to connect with nature, whatever their age, and it doesn’t have to cost much money.'

Text: 'I started playing football when I was 7 years old. I would hurry home from school to play with other boys and girls. I loved it, and after some time, I became a good player. My family knew I often liked new hobbies and then stopped them, so they thought I would do the same with football. But I didn’t stop. I was already dreaming of playing football professionally when I grew up. The chance came sooner than I thought. I often played in local games, and one of the referees saw that I was a good player. He asked the manager of a professional women’s club to watch me play. After that, she asked me to join her club. I didn’t believe it at first – I didn’t know young girls could join women’s clubs. But the manager liked me, and I started training with a big club when I was 13 years old. After that, I got much better. Still, some people didn’t think I would be a star player, which made me a bit sad. But the coach told me to be myself and believe in myself – he even let me play in one of the club’s important matches, much earlier than I thought! I ran very hard – I didn’t want the other players to blame me for losing. Then, by luck, I scored the winning goal. Even with the big crowd, I could hear my coach cheering for me, and after the match, the team carried me around the field. It was fantastic! Since then, I’ve scored many more winning goals! Next month, my coach and I are organizing a football tournament in my area. The goal is to get teenagers interested in football and to let them talk to other players in my club. It will show them the professional environment and encourage them to think they could play for a top team if they work hard. But my advice to them will be the same as my coach gave me – you’ll have good times, but be ready for bad times too. I’ve had very few bad times, though – so I’ve been lucky!'

Text: 'In the UK and other countries, schools and universities are now encouraging students to start doing research early in their studies. Research is not just for famous scholars or scientists. It is a way to learn and build skills. Research skills are useful in school and at work. As a student, you help create knowledge. You do this by asking questions like Why? How? When? What does this mean? These questions are part of research. Research can be very complex or it can be simple, like asking questions about everyday things. Most students have done some research before, like for school projects or at work. You also do research when you plan a holiday, grow plants, fix things, train a pet, or shop online. In college, you need to ask questions, explore information, and create your own ideas. Some students find this hard because in some places, knowledge is seen as something you get from teachers and books. But in the UK, US, and other places, you are expected to question what you learn. This can be challenging. Critical thinking is important in research. We need to think about what we read and hear, and not just accept it as true. We should check if the information is logical and supported by evidence. We should not just believe everything we are told.'

Text: 'Cities have always been places where people think and create new ideas. In the 18th century, people in London met in coffee houses to talk about science and politics. In modern Paris, artist Pablo Picasso talked about art in cafés. But living in a city is not always easy. The same London coffee houses also spread diseases like cholera. Picasso moved to the countryside later. Cities are full of creativity, but they can also be stressful and unnatural. Scientists are now studying how cities affect our brains. They found that city life can make us tired and less able to think clearly. One reason is the lack of nature. Studies show that hospital patients get better faster when they can see trees. Even a small view of nature helps our brains because it gives us a break from city life. More people now live in cities than ever before. We live in crowded places with many strangers. This can affect our mental and physical health. Walking in a busy city street, our brain has to pay attention to many things: people, traffic, and noise. This is tiring because our brain has to decide what to focus on. Nature, on the other hand, is relaxing and doesn't need much effort from our brain. This idea is called attention restoration theory. Psychologist Stephen Kaplan says that being in nature helps our brain relax and recover. Parks in cities, like Central Park in New York, give people a break from city life. A walk in a park can help our brain work better. People try many things to improve their thinking, like energy drinks or changing office designs, but being in nature is very effective. So, why do cities keep growing? Even with the internet, cities are still places of new ideas. Research shows that the busy and crowded parts of cities help people be creative. Just like 18th-century London, modern cities like Cambridge, Massachusetts, are centers of new ideas. The challenge is to keep the good parts of city life while reducing the stress. Sometimes, people want to leave the city and enjoy nature, but they also love the excitement of city life.'

Text: 'Where is the mind? This might seem like a strange question. We usually think that thinking happens inside our heads. Today, we have special machines that can show this. But I believe the study of the mind should not stop at the head. There is a lot of evidence, from ancient times to now, that things outside our heads also help us think. For example, in archaeology, we see that stone tools, jewelry, carvings, clay tokens, and writing systems have helped humans think and grow. So, maybe what is outside the head is also part of the mind. 

We often think the mind and brain are the same because scientists study people without the things around them. This is because brain machines need it this way. But much of our thinking happens outside our heads. I do not question that the brain is important for thinking, but I think the mind is more than just the brain. Human intelligence might spread into culture and the world around us. This is where my new idea, Material Engagement Theory (MET), comes in. MET looks at how things become part of our thinking, like when we make numbers from clay or use a stone to make a tool. It also studies how this has changed over time and what it means for our thinking.

Think of a blind person with a stick. Where does this person’s self begin? The stick and the person work together, showing how our minds and things are connected. The stick helps the blind person feel the world, and the brain treats the stick as part of the body. This shows that human intelligence can change by using new tools. My idea sees the human mind as always changing and growing. 

It is important to remember that, in history, the 'stick' could be anything from old stone tools to the internet. The main job of the 'stick' is to help us understand the world, not to limit us. Humans use 'sticks' to learn and know more. This is why humans make things, and these things help shape our minds. I call this metaplasticity – our minds change as they interact with the world. MET helps us understand how different tools, from old axes to smartphones, change who we are and how we think. Technology that changes the mind sounds like science fiction, but humans have used it since they first appeared.'

Text: 'Photography is an invention that has changed how we see the world. In the United States, photography became important in many areas, like science, industry, art, and entertainment. Historians say photography is one of the US's biggest contributions to art. To understand its impact, we need to look at its start in the mid-19th century. Why did people like this new art? First, photography was a mechanical process, which matched the US's love for technology and change. Like trains and electricity, photography made the world feel smaller by showing us new places and things. Second, people used cameras to show their identity and family. Photos gave families a way to keep memories, even if they were a bit idealized. Third, photos were realistic and matched the US's love for realism in art. A photo shows what the photographer wants us to see, saying, "Look at this!" Photos are records of events, people, and things, showing what was in front of the camera. But, because a person takes the photo, it also shows their point of view. We might think we understand a photo because we know the subject, but its meaning can be complex. A photo's meaning can change depending on where and how we see it, like in a newspaper or a gallery. To understand a photo, we need to know why it was taken and how people first saw it. The same photo can mean different things in different places and times. Artists now use photos in their work. Since Andy Warhol, artists have included photos in paintings and other art forms. Photography is now an important part of art, working together with painting.'

Text: 'In 1890, William James, an American philosopher and doctor, called psychology the 'science of mental life.' This is still a good way to start understanding psychology today. We all have thoughts and feelings, so we have some idea of what mental life means. Psychology can be studied in animals like rats and monkeys, but it is mostly about humans. James thought human psychology had basic parts: thoughts and feelings, the world around us, and how we know about these things. Our knowledge is personal and comes from our own thoughts and experiences. Sometimes, we think we know why people act a certain way, like feeling unhappy or quitting a job. But people can see things differently. Psychology tries to find out which explanations are correct. Psychologists help us see the difference between our own ideas and scientific facts. They study the mind and brain, but they do not know everything about how the brain works. Instead, they learn by watching how people behave. Psychology is like solving a puzzle. It uses clues from careful observation and logical thinking. Psychology wants to describe, understand, predict, and change things it studies. It helps in many areas, like teaching children to read or helping people with their feelings. Psychology has been studied scientifically for about 150 years. Early psychologists used introspection, which means looking at their own thoughts, but this has limits. Today, psychologists prefer to study the behavior of others.'

Text: 'In a simple building in Michigan, USA, there is a place called the Museum of Failed Products. This museum has many products that people did not want to buy. For example, there is A Touch of Yogurt shampoo and Breakfast Cola. These products were taken off the market because they did not sell well. The museum is owned by a company called GfK, and Carol Sherry is in charge of it. She thinks each product has a sad story for the people who made and sold it. The museum is a business that makes money, which is surprising. Many companies do not keep their failed products, so they come to this museum to see them. The museum started by accident. Robert McMath, who worked in marketing, wanted to collect all kinds of products, not just the ones that failed. He started doing this in the 1960s. He found out that most products do not succeed. This is why the museum has so many failed products. People often think positively and do not see when a product will fail. Sometimes, marketers spend more money on a product that is not selling to try to make it work. People do not like to talk about why a product failed. In the self-help world, people believe that thinking positively can make good things happen. But psychologist Gabriele Oettingen found that thinking too much about success can make people less motivated. Carol Dweck, another psychologist, says that how we see failure depends on what we believe about ability. Some people think ability is natural, while others think it can grow with effort. People who believe in natural ability find failure very hard. But people who believe in growing ability see failure as a chance to learn and get better. This way of thinking is happier, even if it does not always lead to success.'

Text: 'Many people know that sports teams often do better when they play at home. But why is this? We might think we know, but sports are changing a lot.
